reviewText: Giving you a brief rundown of where I stand, I thought the 1st "Superman" was ok. I actually enjoyed Part 2 better; part 3 was my favorite; and even though part 4 got a lot of harsh criticism, I didn't think it was so bad. I kind of liked it.Onto the subject at hand. I understand that this movie was an uphill battle at best and a doomed failure at worst. I understand that most people already had the irrevocable image of Christopher Reeve as Superman. But this already difficult battle was not handled well.For one thing, this movie tries to be consistent with Part 1 and 2. (It shows images of Marlon Brando from Part 1, and having Lex Luthor know about Superman's base from Part 2.) BUT, this movie seems to forget that the death of Superman's 'earth' mother was mentioned in Part 3, and that Superman made arrangements to sell the family farm in Part 4.The main problem here is that the movie does NOT remain consistent with the 1st 4; NOR DOES IT MAKE A CLEAN BREAK AND START FRESH. (Making a clean break and starting fresh was probably the best bet for this difficult uphill battle.)Moving on, it almost gets annoying when it at least seems that Rooth is imitating Christopher Reeve. He may have been better off just bringing his own style to the role. Something like this happened recently.After 2 Harry Potter movies, Richard Harris (who did Dumbledore) died. He was beloved in this final role. Now when Sir Michael Gambon took the role from part 3, he was smart enough not to imitate Richard Harris. He knew this was a difficult spot. So he just did Dumbledore with his own style. (Probably Sir Michael Gambon's smartest move under the circumstances.)Well, back to Superman. His jealousy over Lois Lane having moved on with her life seems a bit unfair. (He did after all leave for some years.) Lois Lane did the healthy thing. She moved on with her life. (She also has a son now.)What saves this movie from being a complete and utter disaster is Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. He has gotten out of jail and now has the family fortune to start new with. He is very bad. But like many of Charles Dickens's villains, he carries a charm that makes him likable in a way. His big plan is to use Kryptonic elements to create a new world, and take over.There is an interesting climactic moment where Lex Luthor leads Superman into a trap, and it's hard not to enjoy seeing Lex Luthor finally get his chance to punch out Superman.Another character worth mentioning is Frank Langella as Mr. White. In his minor (but still significant) role, he adds a bit of charm. Lois is starting to feel bad about her book: "Why the World Does Not Need Superman." And with some charm, Frank Langella says: "Don't worry Lois. People won't remember what you got the Pulitzer Prize for. They will just remember that you got it."Believe me, I TRIED to be open to this film. I TRIED to give it a fair chance. I TRIED to understand that Brandon Routh had a very difficult if not impossible task. But it just didn't work. I give the movie 1 star for Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, and 1 star for Frank Langella. Another annoying element is that if the movie takes place some years after Part 2, why do the characters look younger than they did in Part 2?SUMMED UP: They had a choice. They could have either remained consistent with the 4 Christopher Reeve movies, or they could have made a clean break and started fresh. AND THE PROBLEM IS THAT THEY DID NEITHER.Being perfectly honest, if you have not seen the 4 Christopher Reeve movies, you may be more able to accept this and enjoy it on its own. But it really doesn't fit with the Christopher Reeve movies.
summary: For Once, Lex Luthor Saves the Day

reviewText: SUPERMAN REPEATSScene stealing is the highlight of this lackluster blockbuster.I mean literally lines lifted from the original don't make it as good, but make it cheating, and like they can't think of ORIGINAL scenes or WIT.It makes you wonder are they doing a remake? Or a recape? And a reboot - with that new costume. Or a rape? But even worse, Big Bird's half a remake. And every stolen take is half-baked. The copycakes.It got embaressing when they start to duplicate a scene, and you think well at least they don't do that completely - and then they do later, like with the music.Oh yeh, and the music not by John Williams stands out like a - another person! It falls flat like Supe without his powers. Why didn't they at least get him? Who shot JW? And then when William's music comes in again it sticks out like a soar-ing man!It makes me sore they can't find an original script writer.At a million a minute, it amazed me what they film.Doing a sequal 25 years later is bad enough and doesn't work, but make it half the same makes less sense!25 years later the new Bluebird has to be as better as the first was then to what was before. But one can achieve only one's goal.I usually hate costume dramas, but usually love this one with one, but the whole film becomes a piece of cape, to boot. In fact, more: it's a cape caper to two boots. But that is entirely inconsequal, like half the film.____________________________________________________________________________________________________________2 MAJOR FLAWSAnd yes, it's insane to have Lex Luther AGAIN. (Imagine if the Batman movies only had the joker.)But more insane is his scheme - in the wrong way. And it all amounts to a huge piece Kraptonite. And as bland as big.I return to The Bird with the Primary Plumage's absence for it must have affected his judgement. In the jet save (yes, not the bat cave), he ignored the most urgent situation to keep on with a finished task. Bizarre. That was doubly odd because he didn't need to do that for the plot, as normally happens.Yet to mention the horrendous injuries the people would have from G-forces all the way in that jet scene, even just the bit viewed in the preview.To say again what I haven't said: This film needs to be remade. Now! Or at least unmade.____________________________________________________________________________________________________________TO REPEAT...There were a few fleeting times when Supe-baby was magic - such as in silent unexpected flight. But not only does the film seem the hotch potch result of all the past troubles, doubts, and revisions in getting it done, but mainly amounts to consistant pale, weak reminders of the first successful film where they did the work - properly! And if you think it's annoying how often I'm repeating that, you get the picture of the film.To reiterate, I regurgitate again what I repeated before on this floor____________________________________________________________________________________________________________SMALLBITSVILLEOne small note. I'd like to know where Superman got the plastic for his insigna. Was it part of the spaceship, or did he get it from a plastics shop? I like it though.And, did S have brown eyes in the beginning, but in every other scene his eyes are blue?And why is his cape and boots mauve? Mauve (n): A moderate grayish violet to moderate reddish purple.Finally, firstly, I want to see a SuperMAN like the comics - with the build of Mr UNIVERSE.THEN he'd look right, instead of annorexic or mere mortal.God knows what the sequal to this one will be - a remake of this one? I mean, it takes remakes one step further, doesn't it, taking Hollywood's entropy further - into insanity?I am over the age of 1300.

reviewText: (SPOILERS!!!) Imagine a guy, lying comatose in a hospital bed, patterned pyamas and all, being visited by the son he doesn't know he has... one of the rare things differing this movie from the Mexican soaps is the absence of Spanish language (I know a lot of people likes this genre, but it doesn't have anything to do with Superman). It was trumpeted for it's faithfulness to Richard Donner's movie, but, in the light of this situation, any refference to it and a quotation feels more like sacriledgeous blow than a nod. Mr. Donner knew and felt what Superman IS all about, and what we get here instead is pathetic soap, interspersed with overblown action scenes. To discuss the fact that any logic is surgically operated out of this movie (eg, Superman stops the plane from crashing in the last moment, becouse of it's weight, and then, afterwards, hurtles the whole mountain consisting partly of KRYPTONITE into space, almost effortlessly) would be beside the point. The music, when it is not any of majestic John William's themes, is simply put awfull, especially contrasted to aforementioned themes, which are very well performed, orchestrated, recorded, and engineered this time, making the situation enven more painful. Well, Bryan Singer never had good music in his movies anyway, but he had good movies so far, so he could get away with that. Also, the logic of casting a cute, but ultimately charisma-and-character-less actress in the role of Lois Lane will forever elude me. Saying all this, I have to point out that I respect Mr. Singer and his work very much, and congratulate him for discovering Brandon Routh (if only he had restrained his emoting a bit, it would not look that he is going to throw up one too many times - otherwise he was great as Superman). All this would be even more of a reason to ask: what was Mr. Singer thinking? Was Superman too super for him? Find out for yourself...
summary: I really wanted to like this movie...

reviewText: "Superman Returns" starts off well - we quickly move through a lot of Superman's back story, because the filmmakers know we've all seen Christopher Reeve's original "Superman."  Indeed, the theme music is the same; Brando's footage and voice as Superman's father are repurposed; this movie clearly acknowledges that the first Superman movie happened and is meant to be placed in the same universe.  Brandon Routh does a credible Christopher Reeve; Kevin Spacey maintains the same tone as Hackman did in the original; and indeed the tone of the picture is very much that of the original "Superman."So why three stars?  First, there just isn't much of a story in this movie.  The first one wasn't a masterpiece of storytelling, but it had plot aplenty compared to this.  Second, "Superman Returns" lacks the iconic moments of the first movie that you remember even years after seeing the film.  Third, this movie isn't so much about Superman as it is about Lois Lane.  My wife pointed this out, and she's right.  Not that Lois Lane isn't an interesting or worthwhile character, but we want to see a movie about Superman when we are watching "Superman Returns."  Instead, Superman is the cipher at the center of this film, a sort of Oliver Twist around whom all manner of events happens, but whom we never really get to know.It's worth a rent, and it's better than Superman III or Superman IV.
summary: Decent, but not as good as the classic

reviewText: At first i was doubtful and the newcomer Brandon Routh being superman but i must say he proved himself worthy to put on the cape. The film itself was well casted, some were better than previous ones i thought. Kevin Spacey i thought played a more serious and ruthless lex luthor than Gene Hackman did. Kate Bosworth herself played a better lois lane who seemed more serious at her job and smarter aswell as beautiful. Frank Langella played a good perry white as Jason Marsden played his nephew. though Marc Mcclure i liked better, Sam Huntington did a decent job. Now for the things i didnt much like in this installment. I didnt care much for the new superman costume design. If this film is to take place after the first two christopher reeve films, why change the design? the colors and material didnt bother me that much, but i thought it would be better if they stuck with the previous design, having the bigger chest S symbol aswell as the yellow S symbol on the cape. Keeping the cape little shorter and not change the belt buckle or boots. i asked numberous of people what they thought and they agreed to keep the color and material but not use the new design. I mean come on, no-one in their right mind is gonna think of superman being a real person. Bryan Singer did a good job though on this movie still as he did with the first two x-men films,theplot was decent for a larger scale plan thats been already done. superman having a kid i thought wasnt too bad, would make sense after what he and lois did in superman 2. but overall i give this a five star sense it earned its place in the franchise. thats all i gotta comment. and id like to think i speak for everyone, but we miss you Christopher Reeve as the world needs and still wants a real-life superman. god bless ya and your wife.

reviewText: "Look up in the sky! It's a bird, it's a plane, no it's Christopher Ree... I mean it's Brandon Routh!"The '06 release of `Superman Returns' is both a nostalgic tribute to the `70's `Superman' films starring the late Christopher Reeve with its incorporation of composer the John Williams original theme and a promising introduction to a new Superman series of adventures tailor made for the 21st century audience.Director Bryan Singer masterful combination of both old and new elements of the Superman Mythos was a stroke of genius, creating for the "Old School" Superman fan a comforting sense of continuity with the earlier films. I openly admit to experiencing an increased heart rate and a childish sense of wonder and excitement the instant I heard that familiar John Williams' theme as part of the new musical score.Along with incredible special effects `Superman Returns' delivers a great new soundtrack and a strong script. Add to the mix a well chosen new superhero played by Brandon Routh and a top notch performance by Kevin Spacey as the villainous Lex Luther and we've got a new cult classic to enjoy over and over again. Now if I could only find that old cape of mine!
summary: "The World Doesn't Need A Savior And Neither Do I" ~ Needed Or Not, Superman Returns

reviewText: I was seven years old in 1978, when my father took me to see Richard Donner's fondly revered "Superman." That film represented my first real exposure to that legendary DC Comics superhero. It, along with Richard Lester's equally memorable "Superman II," has forever shaped my worldview of what Superman, the actual character, is all about.And then along came Bryan Singer, the one man brave enough to breathe new life into the Man of Steel after films III and IV very nearly destroyed his cinematic aura forever. A great many of us appear to harbor the impression that Mr. Singer had dropped the ball in a rather obtuse manner when he decided to helm this feature over "X-Men 3."Clearly, I must digress.Having experienced "Superman Returns" once in the theater, I can now say in all honesty that I will never again listen to cynics or couch-critics. This was an affectionate and extremely well-crafted two and a half hour diversion from reality. We all seem to feel obligated to compare new films such as this to the older releases that inspired them. Why can't we just enjoy a film like this on its own merits? It isn't entirely outside the realm of reason, especially when you take into account that it's only a movie we're talking about in the first place. I saw quite a bit of the late Christopher Reeve within Brandon Routh's portrayal, and the casting of Kevin Spacey was nothing short of brilliant. His Lex Luthor, for me, was just as memorable as Gene Hackman's. I have to be honest and admit that watching this film was tantamount to reliving the one part of my childhood that I never really abandoned. That would more accurately entail my sense of enthrallment, the pure and innocent wonder I felt as a boy while watching Superman save the day.I really tend to believe that most of those people who, for whatever reason, did not enjoy this film are picking it apart for all the wrong reasons. Nothing Bryan Singer brings to this movie is any less difficult to accept than the plot structure employed by Donner or Lester. "Superman Returns" is true to the spirit of the first two films and is a more than fitting addition to any fan's collection.Bravo, Bryan, bravo!!!

reviewText: I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. They did an excellent job of honoring the original Christopher Reeve movies while also creating their own fresh, modern take on Superman's story. Though it struck me as an odd choice to cast Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane, there's no doubt that Brandon Routh was perfectly cast as Clark Kent/Superman, and Kevin Spacey did a respectable job as Lex Luthor. The story of Superman's return to Earth, why he was gone for so long, as well as the twist at the end of the movie, were all well done. I also like that this movie didn't go the obvious route of yet another version of the love story between Superman and Lois. There was so much more to this movie that their relationship barely factored into it. Lois had moved on to someone else and was still completely oblivious to the fact that Clark is Superman. Maybe they'll focus more on a Superman/Lois romance in the next film. I would only suggest that the sequel be a little shorter on time. This movie could have used a bit more editing, but it was still exciting to watch as well as heartwarming. Highly recommended!

reviewText: I love this sequel, even though some people downplay it.Why do I call it a sequel to CR's Superman 2?If you haven't seen Superman 2, STOP READING, and go watch Superman 1 and Superman 2. If you can, watch the extended versions of each one. (The extended version of Superman 1 includes Kirk Alyn and Noel Neill playing little Lois Lane's parents. Kirk and Noel played Superman and Lois Lane in the 1940's Superman Serial.)In the second Reeve Superman movie, Superman voluntarily gave up his powers, temporarily, and while powerless, had sex with Lois Lane. Then after gaining his powers back, he hypnotized Lois into forgetting the entire incident.In Superman Returns, Kal-El returns to Earth after spending five years journeying in a rocket to Krypton space and back, looking to see if anyone survived. (The fact that he found an intact piece of Argo City implies we might see a Supergirl Movie someday.)Superman Returns to discover that Lois has a son. During the length of this movie, he learns more and more about little Jason, and obviously realizes that Jason must be his son. He doesn't see, but we do see Jason surprising himself with sudden bursts of superpowers, like pushing the piano over onto the thug that was threatening his mother.Unfortunately, the novelization of Superman Returns leaves out the details about Jason's superpowers. I had so hoped to see more about Jason's powers in the book.So, if the matter of Jason's powers didn't make sense to you, be sure to go back and watch Superman 1 and 2. I also enjoyed the fact that the producers put details in, to honor the memory of Chris Reeve, like letting Superman remind us of scenes from the CR movies. When Superman told the people on the plane that he hoped the experience didn't put them off flying, and how flying was still the safest form of travel (not an exact quote), he was, in my mind, telling Lois, "Yes, I remember the first time we met, it had to do with flying."I hope you enjoyed this movie as much as I did, and I hope you go back and watch the earlier movies. And don't forget Kirk Alyn as Superman in the Serials, George Reeves in the 1950's TV Adventures of Superman, and the old 1940's Radio Superman, which you can download for free at ARCHIVE.ORG.John
summary: a SUPER sequel, follows Christopher Reeve's Superman 2

reviewText: I have to say first, I'm not a comic book fan. I've never read, nor will I ever read any sort of comic book. I am, however, a movie fan. I loved the first two Chris Reeve Superman Movies, (3 and 4 were just dreadful) and I was hoping that with this reincarnation it would bring back the awesomeness of the first two. It seems that with Superman Returns for whatever reason it decided to become a sequel, but not a proper sequel, just a sequel where they change things that happened in the past which we know didn't happen because we watched the first four movies. (The last two, yes unfortunately)I'm going to touch on quite a few things that I noticed in this movie where I raised one eyebrow and thought, WTF? The first one is the main one that I think most people will have noticed and genuinely asked the question. What were they thinking? OK, Superman had left Metropolis to find the remains of his home planet which had apparently been discovered by astronomers. This was something that had happened after Superman 4, and now he returns to jump back into the job he abandoned and make friends with the bitter Lois Lane. This is what annoyed me. Lois Lane, for whatever reason had suddenly forgotten that Clark Kent was Superman? Forgive me if I'm wrong here but didn't she find out his real identity in the first Superman Movie? I know this film wasn't billed as an actual sequel, but if you're going to name a movie Superman Returns, and it's released 28 years after the original Superman movie then you have to at least keep it consistent because you have a lot of people at least expecting a bit of a sequel feel to it.The other thing I wanted to poke at was something another reviewer has also mentioned. This is a comic book movie, correct? This is a movie based on a man from another planet who's pretty much invincible, correct? Then why is it that with this sequel they had the beauty of CGI and the ability to bring a crazy villain (rather than Luthor) to go against Superman. Why don't we get some real comic book action in this film? Spiderman did it, The Incredible Hulk has done it, hell even the Dark Knight has done it. So why did Superman not bother? Why did Singer, Harris & Dougherty decide to give us a soap operatic movie that simply, Superman fans weren't after. Sure the Lois reunion would have been cool and to see her moved on would have been interesting, but this was the whole damn movie. Superman returns to Earth to find that a bitter Lois had written a Pulitzer prize winning article on "Why the Earth doesn't need Superman." Lois has moved on and she's now in a new relationship with the unlikeable Richard played by James Marsden and has a child to him. Sure a new relationship storyline is fun and all but this consumed the entire movie and the Lex Luthor's insane plot was overshadowed by that.That's not the icing on the cake, you're going to love this ridiculousness. The kid, while on a boat being kidnapped by Luthor, along with Lois by the way. Lois is being approached by one of the henchmen who's ready to beat the crap out of her, then BAM!!! out of nowhere a piano flies into the face of the henchman. So the child is the child of Superman, remember Lois can't remember who Superman really is, she's forgotten. Nothings confirmed though, you see it could have been just one of those crazy feats of strength that you hear people have on the news.I've got nothing else to say, apart from this is THE worst superhero movie EVER. I know that may be a bit of an exaggeration, but I can assure you I'm not. This is even worse than the Batman & Robin movie from 1997 because at least that had more fighting and action. In Superman Returns we were presented with about three major action scenes and they were literally no longer than 5 minutes. Brandon Routh can make a good Superman and Spacey a good Luthor. Bosworth needs to be dropped as she's just terrible as Lois Lane. I'm only hoping that in the sequel entitled Man of Steel (the DC movies are creating a theme with comic book movies now, just look at The Dark Knight, sequel to Batman Begins) the cast have another bout of amnesia and the child and the poor relationship are forgotten about and we can be given a real comic book movie from the new Superman. I would like to see an intergalactic villain in the sequel, maybe Metallo or Doomsday?Terrible movie, stay away.
summary: What Made Superman Become So Dull In His Rebirth.

reviewText: All he does is fly around and lifts heavy objects! The three main action scenes in this film involves him flying around and lifting heavy objects to save people, in the DVD cover is him lifting a plane from the dramatic though a bit too long scene in the film...I don't know why they chose that image for the cover artwork, I preferred the movie poster of him standing over the world. If they had chopped a half hour off this movie I'd of probably liked it even more...Brandon Routh is a worthy successor, IMO better than Christopher Reeve who always came across as geeky even in his Superman tights...Routh better make more demands monetarily when they do the follow-up as the stories that have been linked show he wasn't very well taken care of doing this movie. Kevin Spacey is the perfect Lex Luthor, as good as Gene Hackman's. Look for a cameo by the original Jimmy Olsen from the old television series playing a bartender. reviewText: I just recently watched the "Christopher Reeve collection" all four Superman movies in a row, so when I watched Superman Returns I had a proper visual in my mind to compare it too. Is it fair to compare them? Of course, because growing up with Christopher Reeve as "the" only superman makes me an expert skeptic, and with all the remakes and rip offs out there now, if you choose to make one you must be open to comparison. Superman is a seminal character in comic book, pop culture and movie history, essentially an alien story he has become the ultimate earth champion. I was afraid that making a new superman movie would pull him out of his gentleman old fashioned movie star ways, and recast him as some idiotic CGI modern superstar. Thank God they got it right!From the opening scene, with Brando's voice I just knew they were going to honor what came before. Brandon Routh is eerily similar to Reeves, both in looks and mannerisms. I am not sure how much of that is planned, or if Routh just carries himself the same way. Kevin Spacey as Lex is also like looking at Gene Hackman they both can carry off the "sneering, comical criminal mastermind", and look darn good bald. In the original movies I personally couldn't stand Margot Kidder as Lois Lane. Kidder never embodied Lane the way the comics fleshed her out to be, a strong reporter headstrong woman but feminine and just a bit nave, She was to abrasive and manly and quite frankly not all that attractive. So I hoped they would cast a better Lois, and that is the only thing they failed in. Kate Bosworth? Who's range of acting roles at this point have been to play surfers and horse lovers and Sandra Dee (who she also messed up). She is really a blonde, and the wig they used for her was awful, too high on her forehead. She is also too skinny and angular and just has one face for every single emotion. Routh deserved a better Lois just as Reeves did. As for the character of Kitty, played by the marvelous genius Parker Posey (who should have been Lane instead) she almost stole that movie altogether.As for the content of this movie, the plot, it was acceptable. They kept it simple and straightforward and executed it correctly without going too overboard and inserting too many CGI moments. (if you have ever read my reviews I abhor the misuse of CGI) the only time I cringed a bit was the close up of Superman flying and it was obviously not a green screen profile. The costumes were magnificent (love the new Superoutfit), the sets were breathtaking,  Bryan Singer made his own Superman, while honoring the old, and that is how it should be.

reviewText: The makers of Superman Returns took this challenge seriously for it's an homage to the Christopher Reeves Superman and, in fact, is dedicated to the Reeves. Shorn of its outdated effects, the CR Superman franchise remains enjoyable because of its characters. Bryan Singer's version with Brandon Routh is darker and deeper than before, but the Superman characterization remains. I never cared for the ditzy Lois Lane of Margot Kidder, so Kate Bosworth's moody one is more effective and sexier (at least for me). Kevin Spacey does his best (and effective) impersonation of Gene Hackman. I particularly enjoyed John Ottman's reworking of John Williams' original themes. Only seeing Kumar do the bully role was a bit disconcerting. Loads of tonge-in-cheek references to previous movies -- Superman and others!12/14/2013Viewed movie again. If the extended Lois Lane "smoking on the rooftop" scene with Superman doesn't move you, you haven't been paying attention. For a "comic book" movie, this scene rivals any "serious" movie for its pathos...only to to be relieved by the choice of "chicken or tofu wrap."

reviewText: I can understand why everyone would want this to succeed, but there are three reasons why it didn't. First of all, you would think Warner Brothers would learn from the reinvention of the Batman franchise they nearly killed. I always thought the target audience should be adults, and then would eventually make it down to kids. This kind of campy storytelling will not be tolerated by the public at large anymore.Secondly, I felt there was some sentimental value attached to this film due to the passing of Christopher and Dana Reeve to not allow a more objective critique of the film. I'm not coming down on Brandon Routh at all. I think he did a wonderful job taking the Superman mantle. Aside from a few poor casting choices (Bossworth and Posey). The cast carries out very good performances. Not surprising was Kevin Spacey's marvelous performance as Lex Luthor. While clearly differing from Hackman's performance. Spacey offers a more jubulent take which adds more depth to the character.And third, what made this film lose its cohesiveness was the direction of the story. Bryan Singer did a great job of re introducing the characters. But after that failed to take the movie in a clear direction. So in truth, you only need to see the first half of the film. After the second half you might end up scratching your head.A shout to the people at Warner Brothers. You boys clearly don't have a clue wether you have a good thing or a bad thing so I'll make this real simple. Either hire a competent writer to tell a good story or sell the rights to make these movies. Superman is a good character with a wealth of material in the mythos to use. And it shouldn't be butchered by the likes of you. Take notice folks, Donner's films are going to out gross this one too.
summary: Superman Returns... but to do what exactly?

reviewText: I had been looking forward to seeing this film for a long time, but after I did, I wish I hadn't. The disappointment was that huge.The acting was atrocious and all over the map. The set design was grand but seemed more like the landscapes of Terry Gilliam's Brazil, rather than the Richard Donner feel of the first two installments in the series.There were plot inconsistencies all over the place and things that just didn't make any sense (example: where did Superman get the spaceship to travel back to earth from if his home planet had been destroyed years ago? Also, why is Superman in such agony when he returns to earth since the film makes it clear that he is always enjoying some R and R in outer space before returning to earth).There was zero spark between Clark and Lois this time around, which compared to Reeve and Kidder, shows just how much the filmmakers missed the mark.And Superman would never have that much trouble stopping a plane from crashing. I mean look at the ease he caught the falling helicopter in the first film. He's Superman, not Bruce Wayne or Peter Paker (actual humans). I think the filmmakers forgot which superhero they were working with.At 150 minutes it is way too long to sustain interest.
summary: a huge disappointment on all levels

reviewText: I watched this movie when it came out and was really thrilled to see it.  I had heard that the guy playing Superman might be a good fit.  He certainly had the look and after watching it, he nailed Christopher Reeve's performance well enough, but he brought nothing else other than cribbing/paying homage to Reeve.The Lois Lane actress was absolutely awful.  Even the Smallville Lois Lane actress got the role right in comparison.  Spacey was great as Lex Luthor: a sophisticated, diabolical genius.  Classic Lex and not nearly as campy as Gene Hackman was.Now to the point of my title: Superman spent the entire movie stalking Lois Lane.  He did not feel majestic, or inspiring, but yet creepy and a tad perverted.  By the end of the movie it becomes obvious, to some extent, why he was stalking Lois, but just because they had a love child does not mean it makes it right.  Supes could have just done an X-Ray vision check and discovered the boy shared similar DNA, but instead Superman just stalks Lois.  Heck, to top it off  Superman is a dead-beat-dad!  What, leaving for 5 years and only coming back because his check of Krypton went poorly, and then discovering he bailed on Lois when she was with child.  Another case of: check that Lois isn't pregnant after their rendezvous by using X-Ray vision on her.  All these facts aside, I also imagined that Superman would have married Lois if he was going to become intimate with her, but no, true to popular cultures view of men, he bails after he has his fun.  He sure is swell!  This point and Kevin Spacey are the two things I remember most strongly about this film and thus ruined the experience for me (Spacey's performance being the only true saving grace).  My point is that this is not Superman by any means.  A womanizer, a dead-beat-dad, and a stalker aren't Superman!  Why doesn't anyone see this?  I feel like I'm taking crazy pills!There were other problems with the film as well, but I could care less.  I am thankful they canned this part of the Superman mythos and are starting again (although I have severe reservations on this as well).In the end this movie is incredibly forgetable and disappointing.  As others have said in other reviews, this was just a homage to the Christopher Reeve Superman's and really just tried to capture the feel of the originals, but failed.  If there hadn't been the Dark Knight Trilogy I would suggest that Warner Bros give up on creating super hero films and just leave it to Marvel to do it right.
summary: How do you spell Superman? S-T-A-L-K-E-R

reviewText: Superman has returned, but I'm not sure he's here to save the day. While the film is visually stunning (and for that, it's certainly at least worth a rental), it lacks a lot in plot and follow through.QUICK SYNOPSIS: Superman returns after having been gone for 5 years(once again, crashing into his mother's farm fields in a meteorite, only this time he's a full grown man instead of a baby). The world has moved on without him. Even the love of his life, Lois Lane, has moved on with someone else. However, it is soon obvious to Superman that the world is in desperate need of a hero, especially after the power hungry lunatic Lex Luther is released from prison and takes up his old "world domination" driven ways.I had many issues with this film, even though I desperately wanted to love it. SPOILER ALERT:One of my main concerns was with one of the major plotlines of the story, and that was the relationship between Superman and Lois Lane. The director of "Superman Returns" explained that he didn't want to diminish anything that the past Superman films have accomplished. He wanted the memory of the past films to be alive and well, so he decided to tell a return story. Superman left...and then came back. However, if that was the case...how come Lois Lane has no idea that Superman is really Clark Kent? Lois was well aware of this fact in the past films...so why not in this one? She has a child with Superman, how can she not know that the man in glasses she sees everyday at work, and treats with a casual indifference, is the father of her child?There was also a lot to be desired in the Lex Luthor plotline. He is supposed to be a supervillian, but the ending of this film is a little lame and disappointing. I was also disappointed that Superman never actually fights anyone! He's Superman, for goodness sake, can't he throw a punch at *someone*! A bad guy, perhaps?And finally, (and this is a very *minor* thing, but me being the animal lover I am, it was very disturbing), there is a small scene in the movie in which Lex Luthor returns home after a long journey to discover that one of his Chihuahuas (which he inherited from a rich old lady on her death bed) has eaten the other Chihuahua. It lay on the floor and chewed on a rib bone amid a pile of dog fur. It was a disturbing visual on so many levels, and it immediately turned me off of the movie. I realize that it was meant to illustrate what a cold-hearted villian Lex Luthor is, but I just don't feel it was necessary.Having said all that, I still think the movie is worth seeing at least once. There are a lot of cool action sequences, and setting and cinematography are incredible. Kate Bosworth was a bit of a poor fit for Lois Lane. Her character came off as a super-bitch to Superman. The rest of the cast were well suited to their characters.If you want to see any kind of cool special features, then you'll need to purchase the 2 disc special edition of this film. The single disc edition has NO special features on it at all. Just the film and a scene selection option.All in all, it's worth a rental at least. I'd rent it first to see if you like it before you decide to purchase it.

reviewText: This movie was awesome! Superman has truly returned, after too long a wait for a new movie to be released. The action is edge of the seat excitement and this movie will have you both biting your nails in anticipation of what will happen next and crying over what does happen. Please allow me give you a taste of just what the movie is about and who is in it, curtosy of the Internet Movie Database.Brandon Routh (Will & Grace, one episode) plays Clark Kent, or Superman if you prefer. He has travelled back to Krypton, his once home planet because astronomers on Earth seem to think that some of it has remained. His journey lasts five years. During that time that he was away, Louis Lane (played by Kate Bosworth, who also played Emma Hoyt in Remember The Titans) has won a Pulitizer Prize for her work on "Why The World Does Not Need Superman." She is also engaged to Mr. Richard White (played by James Marsden, who also played Scott Summers/Cyclops in the X-men movies) and has one son, Jason White (played by Tristan Lake Leabu, his debut movie).Superman returns to Earth and goes back to work at the Daily Planet, to find his friend, Jimmy Olsen (played by Sam Huntington, who also played Mimi-Siku in Disney's Jungle 2 Jungle) waiting for him.Now, Lex Luthor (played by Kevin Spacey, who also played David Gale in The Life of Davie Gale) ends up finding Kryptonite and has a dream of making a new land mass so large, it will take over the other continents by literally putting them underwater. Can Superman stop Lex this time? Let me just remind you not to think, "Superman is the good guy. Of course he beats Lex." Lex Luthor has an immense amount of Kryptonite, which is a radioactive substace from Krypton that will hurt Superman. It could even kill him. Will it? Is this the final Superman movie? Will Superman return again? Just how strong is The Man of Steel?What are you waiting for? Go now, faster than a speeding bullet, be more powerful than a locomotive, be able to leap tall buildings in a single bound, and get this movie."It's a bird. It's a plane. It's..." "Did you want to see me?"-Superman Returns, a Warner Brothers picture. Directed by Bryan Singer, who aslo directed X2: X-men United.
summary: Anyone can wear a cape, but only C. Reeve is Superman!

reviewText: The cast are all marvelous, and the special effects are great.  Brandon Routh is a great Superman.  The "hook" of this film is very appealing: Superman has been gone for nearly five years, and has to remind the woman he loves, and the world, that he still matters.This is a daunting task that weighs heavily upon our hero.  With almost every frame, we are reminded of how ironic Superman's existence is: the world loves him, looks up to him, yet he is totally disconnected from it.Now here's what I didn't like.  This film pretty much sticks to the same formula as the 1978 film.  Lex Luthor, Superman's arch enemy, is just a wealthy thug.  In the more modern comic, he actually becomes president of the United States.  He's still evil, but he manages to fool the masses into thinking that he's good.  The Lex of the present- day comic book is smarter, more manipulative, and less comical than the Lex of yesteryear.  Lex's "respectability" and greater aptitude for deception makes him a more formidable opponent in today's Superman Comic.This could have been an interesting scenario for this series, but seems unlikely given the ending of this film.But we'll see...EXCUSE ME WHILE I RANTCountless people keep comparing Routh to Reeve, Spacey to Hackman, etc.  This is  absurd! The first Reeve film is now 18 years old!  People should respect the fact that this is a very different vision for a different generation.  Going back to the Richard Donner version  as a point of comparison is anoying and silly.  This film should be viewed on ITS OWN MERITS.

reviewText: And so the Superman franchise is given another lease once more just right after Supe's WORLD'S FINEST buddy Bats gets the same treatment of the movie productions incorporated for DC Comics, in its attempt to revamp their characters back in the action of the celluloid biz, that according to this flick - Supes's been cited in Manila at 10:15.Thus, with the red-caped crusader's continued crusade for truth, justice, and the american way is further portrayed on screen-- just got home from watching the flick myself on IMAX at the  Philippines' first cinema with the said 3D enhancers this fourth of July that's now recognized as the Filippine-American Friendship Day, that I happen to meet one of the country's legendary bands JUAN DELA CRUZ' half-american/Pilipinoe member Joey "Pepe" Smith quite incidentally after the flick around the area, who've thirty years ago opened for the BEATLES' infamous visit on the country. Hm, kinda like some synchronicities it seem. And yep, got eyed by a real pretty american chick as well along the way...Now, before I talk about the whole IMAX thing, first about the movie itself: not to put a level of high expectation, I was ready to say that it's a good rendition of revamping the SUPERMAN mythos, and the IMAX effects gave it a spectacular touch -- but eventually with the SUPES plotline having been rebuffed quite one too many times now to the point of overkill mainly with the romantic innuendo's done about between LOIS LANE and CLARK KENT, one can't help but cite a lot of predictability going on with the storyline's twist and turns, and thus its not a-web swingin'.And also along the lines with this- the ghost from the SALKIND production movie series have haunted this one at the most, which not only have the score of John Williams from the previous movies re-used within the movie itself (in spite that its musical score provided by John Ottman are on level as some splendid successor to soar in this Superman flick) - it also used segments of Marlon Brando from the first SALKIND production flick (which featured SUPERTRAMP's song "Give A Little Bit" playing on the car of Lois Lane at one scene) wherein he plays Supes' dad Jor-El, and a lot of plot elements from the previous films as well, that thus makes the movie a sequel that's not really necessarily a sequel of sorts to the SALKIND Superman flicks, and it also includes a plotline that had a lot to deal with the second installment from those movies, the sequel SUPERMAN II - which in the result cracks a very big whole in its plot - being that Supes is taken away of his Superbeing (ie. Powers) when he cracked the arse of Lois Lane at that time (you'd get the idea about this matter once you've seen the flick, no pun intended) - which in that respect only characterizes the kind of a typical american fictionary stuff, whenever.AS FOR the IMAX treatment = it actually only go for four scenes within the flick, being that the movie is not really intendedly made for an IMAX movie fare, they've only enhanced selected parts of the flick for the 3D enhanced segment portions.That to speak of, the whole innovation from the traditional 3D effect that IMAX came up with is nothing new - 'twas innovated at first with the View Master toyline of disc reels implemented by the company called GAF back in the late 60's and the 70's -- and then tis made possible with movies, by the likes of JAWS 3D, wherein glasses for the 3D movie don't have to be consistedly required of a half red lense while the other lense's green, but a grey one that gives a sturdy condition for the 3D moving pictures' quality in comprising the 3D movie as a whole.But being that the company who came up with the 3Dimentional movie effect is a small one, they gladly sold the rights as incorporated upon syndication to IMAX - who added the touch of an 8-story screen, plus surround sound enhancements, and now they bill it with bigger packaging if not the budget for selling it to the masses. However, the trailers shown for those that are made by the IMAX movie group are quite pretty neat - they are impressive. Most impressively the one titled TYRANOUSSOROUS REX -- ooh, i'd like ta give her a grab a-hold.Anyhow, for the cast and crew: director Bryan Singer did the story for the flick, along with Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris, who both did the screenplay. This time executively produced by a certain Chris Lee among others - it featured Frank Langella as Perry White (who coincidentally just lately starred on the flick called 10.5 APOCALYPSE that was featured on the boob tube, with the shape of America in its storyline turned much too peculiarly similar with the way Lex Luthor in this flick (which is here portrayed by Kevin Spacey, who did a na-bad performance of the character/arch-nemesis of Supes, next to his predecessor Gene Hackman) envisioned it to become), and a host of others that are none-too notable at all.Another glitch in the storyline that makes this movie hard to squeeze in as a real part of the previous Superman flicks, is that Clark's mom Martha is still living, when she's reportedly already gone dead in SUPERMAN 3!And in closing as for the guy who played the red-caped crime fighter this time, Brandon Routh- nyeah, he may have the affiliation to cut himself as a real ticket for being the next dip hearthrob, but in this flick he is more often unnatural to fit the bill of the main Supes-character, that with computer jitz-effects paving the way to enhance him itself - it's all so well forced. It looks so artificial so much so with the flying effects, that it depended not to use strings that much for the effects' sequences but on inanely boring computer fx which only makes it lose its magic even more.I say, given under that projection, might as well watch the classic Supes cartoon of Max & David Fleischer, who's series about are conveniently now available on video or DVD.For the role of the superduper caped crusader, nobody else tops the bill quite obviously as in the case of Robert Powell playing the role of Christ on Franco Zeffirelli's JESUS OF NAZARETH flick - that for this case no ones fits perfectly to play Superman but no other than the late actor himself, Mr. Christopher Reeve.crutchead's ratings =IMAX enhancements: 7 out of 10Movie: 2 1/2 out of 5 notchessound effects: 3. 10 on the Richter scaleoverall rating: 6 burritoes + one onionmusic's not bad, though really.THIS IS review #123 btw, for these here your friendly online convenient store AMAZON.Com, -- oops! 'Nuf of those lines -Spidey might have our hides.

reviewText: Okay, I'm a pretty jaded person when it comes to movies. There is a lot of junk out there. More than ever before. Tired of the same ol' same ol. Tired of the excessive ratio of 5-to-1 horror movies shot by your neighbor on the video shelves. Tired of talentless people getting GOLDEN opportunities to star in films and less then average screenplays getting green lit.That being said... I'm not NEAR as jaded as some of these SUPERMAN geeks who are whining about the costume (ENOUGH ALREADY). They've read so many comic books so many times that they can't bare to see ANYTHING altered.That being said. SUPERMAN turns out being what going to the movies is all about. An adventure. Escapism. If you're going into this movie LOOKING for things to complain about, I feel sorry for you. ME, I found myself wrapped up in a film more than I've been in a long time. I felt the dread. I felt the emotional moments. I laughed and I cried (well... I didn't cry, but I welled up once... I'm a new Dad... give me a break).Superman has it all. Most importantly, Bryan Singer (the director), did what a lot of these superhero films are forgetting to do (i.e. see fantastic 4... er, don't), that is, get the audience EMOTIONALLY INVOLVED.SUPERMAN's opening sequence sets the stage wonderfully. As his ship crash lands once again in the Kent family farm in Smallville, Kansas, you wonder briefly if we're looking back in time, rehashing, and then his earthbound mother finds him in the wreckage, cradles him and says, "Clark. My son."Many things have changed. Most noteably, Lois Lane is now married with son. Lex Luther is free from prison and SUPERMAN wastes no time realizing that the world was missing him.I won't give away things, because SUPERMAN has surprises. But, I will say that KEVIN SPACEY brings Lex Luther to life. He is phenominal, kooky, funny, insane and dangerous. You feel the dread. You feel the danger in the plan he is concocting. I mean... how to do you defeat the unbeatable man of steel? Well, the creators of this new version of SUPERMAN hooked me.I think, Kevin Spacey, in a lot of ways... made the film.The film is gifted with comedy, nostalgia, action, romance, dread, surprises and heroism, and despite what some are criticizing, this IS, WITHOUT QUESTION, one of, if not THE BEST Superhero movie to come along in a long time. Many of the tactics and techniques used in this film will set the standard for future hero films.
summary: SUPERMAN dares to attempt to touch heart strings

reviewText: I'm incredibly torn over how I feel about Bryan Singer's "Superman Returns." On the one hand, it has enough heart to render anyone within a five-mile radius deeply moved. It's not just a meaningless gathering of action, mayhem, and special effects; it actually goes deeper by presenting a story filled with complexity and emotion, all in the face of stylized danger. I'm afraid I can't describe that aspect any further because doing so would give away some really important plot points. Let's just say that Superman's return enables a wealth of repressed feelings to resurface, some of which have been kept secret for a long time. This alone is enough for a recommendation.However, I had some major problems with the film as a whole, and that brings me to the other hand. As classic and well loved as Superman is, this new story doesn't do much to enhance his reputation. Nor does it make it worse; what it does do is prevent him from transcending his well-established image. It's so well established that he practically vanishes behind a gigantic cliche. As I watched "Superman Returns," I came to the realization that he's really not that interesting a character anymore. We live in an age when heroes like Spider-Man, Batman, and the X-Men rake in the big bucks at the box office. True, they were all created in comic book stories many, many years ago. But through the talents of screenwriters and directors, they've been able to stay fresh, energetic, and edgy on the big screen. Superman, however, is exactly the same as he was when he started out back in the late 1930s. Even today, he can dodge bullets and lift heavy objects. He still has x-ray vision, and he can still shoot lasers from his eyes and blow frost onto a fire. And he still believes in truth, justice, and the American Way.I suppose now you can see why I'm so torn over this film. I loved its humanity but was disappointed by its lack of originality. I was also disappointed by Superman's overall look. Replacing Christopher Reeve is Brandon Routh, a young man whose role called for him to be dressed in a rubberized suit and for his hair to be overly slick and shiny. I thought he looked more like a plastic Ken doll than a real person. Looking so fake and pristine doesn't exactly add to his credibility as a character. However, it does help that his physique and facial expressions bear a striking resemblance to Reeve's. Somehow, I found that it gave the entire project legitimacy; Routh recaptures a wonderful performance as established in Richard Donner's original 1978 film.One of the best things about that film was the opening sequence. It showed the credits flying towards the camera amid shots of outer space, all the while playing John William's triumphant main theme. "Superman Returns" opens in much the same way, and it includes William's theme (interwoven throughout the film with John Ottman's original score). But this time, the credits move so quickly that you barely have time to notice any of the names. Luckily, few people care about reading names at the beginning of a movie; all they're really interested in is getting lost in the story, which in this case is incredibly interesting. Superman returns to Earth after an intergalactic journey to the remains of Krypton, his former home planet. Apparently, pieces of it had recently been discovered, and it forced him to wonder whether or not the planet was, in fact, completely destroyed. Of course, we all remember the destruction scene from the first movie (if you don't, this new movie takes a couple of seconds to remind you).After reuniting with his widowed mother, Martha (Eva Marie Saint, whose character is barely developed), he returns to Metropolis as the clumsy Clark Kent and gets his old job back at the Daily Planet. All the important characters are still there. First, there's Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington), the good-natured but undeniably geeky photographer. Then there's the head honcho, Perry White (Frank Langella), a man that's always ready for the next big scoop. Finally, there's Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), the headstrong reporter. Upon his return, Clark is surprised to learn that Lois has since gotten involved in a relationship and has had a child. He also learns that she had written an article entitled "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman" (which, interestingly, earned her a Pulitzer Prize). He realizes then that his untimely disappearance turned her bitter and resentful. She even seems to behave strangely towards the Clark Kent alter ego, never really interested in giving him the time of day despite not seeing him in many years. (Why no one could see the coincidence there is beyond me; I think it's gotten to the point where not realizing Clark Kent and Superman are one and the same is implausible.)Superman first reappears in public after he prevents a jet plane from crash landing. It was a plane that just happened to have Lois as a passenger (covering a story, no less). This heroic stunt is the first of many encounters that forces her to reassess her feelings. Yes, she does love her boyfriend, Richard (James Marsden), and rightfully so; he's a good-natured, friendly man, and he cares deeply for Lois and their son, Jason (Tristan Lake Leabu). But Superman was always the one she truly loved, and that brings on a multitude of conflicting emotions. It gets even more intense when she begins to notice the way Superman and her son have formed a subtle yet significant connection.Of course, no "Superman" story would be complete without the inclusion of Lex Luthor, the evil criminal mastermind whose hatred of the flying goody-two-shoes is only surpassed by his lust for world domination. Taking the reigns from Gene Hackman is Kevin Spacey, who gives Luthor a diabolical edge that served the film well. This is not just in terms of the story; it's also in terms of the genre. Only a comic book villain could think up grandiose schemes that could never be accomplished in real life. Most of the time, they involve large gadgets, unheard of technologies, and the proposed death of millions.Luthor adheres strictly to that mindset, always being able to conjure up delightfully over the top ideas. In the original film he attempted to sink the entire California coast by launching a missile into the San Andreas Fault. Now he intends to literally create his own continent in the middle of the ocean, a feat that can only be accomplished with special crystals. Specifically, he needs the self-generating crystals that make up the structure of Superman's Fortress of Solitude. Naturally, he has the power and resources to collect everything he needs. The most unnecessary resource was his Pomeranian-loving female companion, Kitty (Parker Posey). Her semi ditzy behavior is not at all compatible to his sophisticated demeanor, and I just couldn't believe he actually wanted to be around her.His careful scheming sets into motion the comic book side of the story, the side that doesn't focus on complexity or meaning so much as it focuses on special effects and entertainment. It would be hypocritical of me to say that I didn't have fun watching those scenes. Let's face it; eye candy is great in a comic book adventure film. But they didn't enliven the experience for me, either. If anything, I felt like I was watching an undeveloped idea, one that never really took off because it was bogged down by unoriginal qualities (such as the fact that "Metropolis" is really Manhattan). But as I said before, the humanity it presents is so touching that it outweighs all the other flaws. It's that aspect of "Superman Returns" I want everyone to see, the one that delves into genuine emotion without getting overly sappy. So am I recommending this movie? Yeah, I guess I am, but just barely (if I could, I'd give it three and a half stars). It's a recommendation made in the hope that the emotional experience will be enough to satisfy you. If it isn't, then don't say I didn't warn you.

reviewText: This was a surprisingly good movie, a surprisingly worthwhile viewing experience and I learned something.  This movie is definitely a keeper beceause for the first time, I realized from Brandon Routh's performance and from the production style that Superman is a heartbroken hero who has no one to talk to.  I sort of ignored that aspect of the character although it was expressed in the Christopher Reeve films.  I was never crazy about the character as a hero but I realize now that it sucks to be Kal-El.  His world is irreversibly gone.  The new story is also a bad one for the hero.  This movie is much better than I expected.  I didn't like the casting from photographs but in moving pictures, both Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth look and express themselves beautifully.  It also helps to cast overqualified character actors Kevin Spacey and Parker Posey.  And Brandon Routh can pull off the same thing that Christopher Reeve did - be beautiful by gazing kindly i.e. evoke being beautiful from within despite whatever either one of them looks like.  Well done!  Someone else trying to do that would most likely look manipulative or drippy.  I absolutely loved how I felt assured listening to Brandon Routh use Jor El's words at the end of the movie.  It sucks to lose your entire world and way of life because of evil.  It makes me want to go in and fix it, just get it done and get it over with once and for ALL because otherwise is unacceptable and unbearable to think of.

reviewText: Even though my review might say otherwise, the original Richard Donner film was merely a good superhero movie and one of the better comic book movies. However, there were just some things that were merely uninteresting, slightly long or just unnecessary. Part II was actually surprisingly good while the less said about III and IV is for everyone's benefit. Stuck in development hell for the better part of a decade, the film finally got lifted off the ground when Bryan Singer, director of the Usual Suspects and first 2 X-Men films came onboard. Thankfully, the ideas of Doomsday riding a mechanical spider have been exorcised and we have a solid entry into the series that will probably disappoint some.It's been 5 years since Superman disappeared, searching for the remains of his home planet, Krypton. Returning, he finds the world is still in trouble and moreso, his love Lois Lane has moved on, with evidence in the Pulitzer winning article "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman". Not only that, but Lex Luthor is out of jail and he's got a mind for another land deal which of course puts the entire United States at risk. And so of course, Superman has to contend with not only Luthor but a woman who doesn't love him anymore and a responsibility that he abandoned.It's slightly eerie at how Superman's career has always been in direct competition or level as DC Comics' other hero, Batman. They both had an excellent first film, a pretty good second film with the next 2 being absolute duds, the worst being the 4th. Superman Returns is like the Batman Begins of the series, only it doesn't restart the series so much as it puts it back on track. Ignoring part III and IV, the film is essentially the "real" Superman III, taking place after II. Is this better than the first one? Relatively speaking I like it better but only by a bit. Newcomer Brandon Routh, while looking a bit too similar to Christopher Reeve, is perfect as bumbling nervous Clark and hero of the Earth, Superman. I never liked Gene Hackman's wisecracking portrayal of Luthor and Spacey manages to have that menace he needed while also providing some humor.(Some of it unintentional: "wrong!") While the rest of the cast is fine, the one misfire is Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. She doesn't give a bad performance really, it's just Lois is supposed to be a feisty gal born out of woman's liberation movement while she plays it as a soft-spoken damsel in distress at times.Well it's a Superman movie so do we get to see superhero stuff? Naturally. Probably the best action scene of the year, Superman has to save a maiden voyage of an airplane attached to a space shuttle has they careen towards space and Earth. It's exciting, energetic and just plain awesome. The rest of the stuff he does is not as ambitious but it's certainly no less cool, bringing out the geek in us that loves to see guys lift up 10 tonne globes. The one thing though is that the effects at times look slightly obvious. The flying though has never been better(except for a really bad digital double shot at the end), with the cape finally have some wind in it, unlike 1978's cape where it just flopped down his legs. Shot on the Genesis HD camera, the film looked sharp in theatre and most likely will on next-gen players but on DVD they look slightly too obvious or grainy. Is the film too long? At times, but it gives the film much needed character moments without being a teenybopper superhero movie for the masses(such as Fantastic Four).Batman Begins to me at times didn't feel exciting, as if it looked exciting but it didn't keep me enthralled. Superman Returns did, only the length and ANOTHER Luthor land mass scheme made it knock down a point or 2 but this is another one on the list for best comic book hero films, and it's about time too.
summary: A welcome return for the Man of Steel
Title: N/A

reviewText: Let's start with the positives:1.) Brandon Routh does a good Chrisopher Reeve impersonation.2.) Kevin Spacey & Parker Posey were pretty good as Luther and Kitty.  I think they captured much of what Hackman and that chick had in the original Reeve movies.3.) The retention of John Williams' Superman theme.4.) Luther's yacht was pretty cool.5.) Luther was bald. I was always disappointed that Hackman wasn't (except at the very end).6.) It was widescreen.7.) It was in color.Ok, i'm grasping at straws now.Now on to the negatives:1.) Brandon Routh was too young to play Superman ...especially a Superman that's supposed to be 5 years older than Reeve in Superman 2.  He looks like he's in transition from SuperBOY to SuperMAN.2.) Kate Bosworth was TOTALLY miscast as Lois.  She was waaaay too young.  She didn't have the right look either.  She had NO personality.  She was boring to watch, and brought nothing compelling to the character.3.) The story. Do i really need to tread this again?  It was tired.  Although it technically hadn't been done already, it sure felt like it had. Lex luther trying to take over the world...AGAIN. In fact, isn't it kinda the same as Superman: The Movie? How about bringing in some of Superman's famous super-villians from the comic books?  In 50 years of live-action Superman offerings, that has almost NEVER been done.  And we have the effects technology to do it very well.  Hey, how about doing an adaptation of the HUGELY successful comic "The Death of Superman?"4.) In addition to this feeling like a re-tread of an old story, i thought the special effects kind of got in the way. To some degree, the effects almost had another-worldly aspect to them, and i felt as though i was in some far-off land, as opposed to a big American city.  Someone compared this to Terry Gilliam's Brazil.  Some of the imagery i found a bit pretentious, as well.  It seems like the filmakers really enjoyed showcasing the effects, without working on the story enough.  When they did break from the effects to talk about plot, i didn't care, as the writing was dull, and subplots were uninteresting.5.) Plot holes...for one, if this kid can hurl a piano across a room, why can't he punch out two henchmen?  And frankly, i'm sick of this notion that because Superman loses his super powers, he suddenly becomes a total wimp, who can be taken down by street toughs and old truckers in diners (Superman II).  I mean he IS afterall still a muscular 30 year-old with years of fighting experience behind him.  Uggghh.6.) Ned Beatty.  Luther needed a dumb hechman like Otis.I wish Bryan Singer (the director) had finished the X-Men trilogy and directed the last film. His first 2 were great.  Yet he threw it all away to do this. And now because of his decision, TWO movies have suffered.  I'm sure i'll get reamed for writing this, but how about Spielberg?  He offered to direct the Star Wars prequels, but Lucas turned him down.  Think of how much better THOSE would have been with Spielberg at the helm.  Lucas makes FANTASTIC epic pictures when he lets someone else direct (Empire Strikes Back, Return of the Jedi, all 3 Indiana Jones films).  Not that Lucas was involved with Superman, but...well, anyway.  I would love to hear other people's suggestions for who would have done a better job with this movie.All that having been said, was it worth seeing?  Of course it was.  Any Superman is worth seeing, especially in the theater.  To be able to see that red cape flapping in the breeze, and John Williams' theme music is worth the price of admission...particularly in the theater.  But to OWN?  Go rent it.  It's worth a rental.  But i doubt you'd watch it again.
summary: Not AS bad as detractors say...but not much better.

reviewText: In my opinion they've yet to find a decent Superman. Christopher Reeve was gawky and uninteresting. Brandon Routh is simply a cardboard copy. In fact, Superman Returns is plagued with bad acting and bad character development. Even the music is old. We've seen and heard everything before. Kate Bosworth makes a dreadful Lois Lane. She neither looks nor acts like a pushy female reporter and was not terribly bright. (Superman and Clark Kent coming back at the same time? Du-uuuuh!)Arguably the best CG in the movie was the scene where Superman saves the plummeting plane from disaster and brings it to rest in the Metropolis Stadium. The scene could have been far more memorable had it been accompanied by great music. Bryan Singer should have recalled the crash landing in the beginning of the last Star Wars movie. That's how a scene like that should be handled.Every modern movie has a chase scene and Superman Returns serves us the same trash that every other action film serves. This time Luthor's girl friend is in a car with no brakes and yet which amazingly remains at 60 mph no matter how many cars and fire hydrants she hits.Superman lowering planes, raising land masses and doing other physically impossible feats works in comics, perhaps, but not in modern movies where audiences are more sophisticated. The movie wastes too much time on contrived action scenes and never develops anyone's character, except possibly Luthor's, and that's primarily because of Kevin Spacey's irrepressible acting ability.Finally, I suspected the true heritage of Lois Lane's son about two seconds after he was introduced. So much for surprises.This film shows why Marvel Comics has the superhero genre wrapped up. Even a bad Marvel film is better than the best DC superhero film, though Batman's return movie was undoubtedly the best of all DC fare.Hopefully, one day the right director will come along and give us a Superman and a Dracula that will knock our socks off. But that day is still a way's off. As for now, both characters must wait for a future "return" of merit. This movie wasn't it for Superman.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In one sentence "good, but could have been better."Overall, this updated Superman - the first since the Christopher Reeve versions a generation ago, is decent but too bland.What this new series needs is some "cool" villains, people fun to watch such as the three escapees from Krypton in Superman II. This series needs a spark that Spacey's "Luthor" didn't deliver. Add more humor, too. The other films had some laugh- out-loud scenes. Give Olsen and Perry some personality. Jack Larson's "Olsen" back on the TV series provided a lot of humor to the show. Get Perry White stirred up. Loosen up Brandon Routh (Superman) and make his character a little more fun, too. This movie would have been so much better with a lot more humor.Kate Bosworth not only is, by far, the prettiest Lois Lane ever, but portrays Lois in a likable fashion. That was nice to see. As for  Routh being the new Superman, I have no complaints. He reminded me a lot of a young Christopher Reeve. I liked the fact that although they played up Superman's feelings toward Lois, they didn't overdo it. They didn't have stupid lines like in 1978 with Superman proving his x-ray vision by telling Lois what color her panties were. In other words, this relationship was not corny or stupid as I felt the Reeve-Margot Kidder one was. Let's hope it stays that way.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Even though the story isn't horrible and Brandon Routh's Chrisopher Reeve impersonation isn't too far off the mark, I found this movie too weak to be part of the permanent Superman Genre.  You know, the way the Peter Sellers "Casino Royale" isn't really a Bond Film.  Of course, I didn't like Superman III with Reeve and never bothered to see Superman IV.What is good about the film?  Well, it has the comic book silliness.  You know, the space shuttle launching from the back of a 747 because it would get more of a boost from them than two solid rocket boosters, and the familiar engines of the shuttle fire powerfully without any observable place for the fuel.  Almost every scene is full of the same kind of nonsense, but it is this daffy disregard for reality is part and parcel of comic books.  I also liked the fact that Superman more or less levitates in this film rather than "flying" like a jet.  Since he has no "thrusters", levitating makes more sense.I hated what they did to his outfit.  The cape and boots are too dark and the "S" signature on his chest is too small and too high.  However, since they were turning the "Man of Steel" into some kind of metrosexual, using the "S" as a bodice rather than a shield or breastplate might make some sort of perverse sense.And the inversion of sexual mores is complete in this film with Lois Lane becoming a single mom, the details of which you will have to learn for yourself by seeing the film.  However, if such a plot point had been used in the original superman, well, one would not have required super hearing to notice the instantaneous outcry from the public.My advice is to treat this film the way the middle "Highlander" films were treated when they decided to get back to the original.  Just ignore it and pretend it never happened and get back to the "real" Superman in the next film.Kevin Spacey played Lex Luthor pretty straight, as a sort of emotionally void killer.  He is smart and an egomaniac, but doesn't have the inner humor of the Gene Hackman Luthor and Spacey never plays for laughs.  I actually liked his performance.
summary: Let's just forget this one and get back to the "real" Man of Steel
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well, here's a little surprise for the ladies out there.  This movie is a great, great romance movie!  Didn't really expect that one but the chemistry that goes on between Superman and Lois is just incredible.  Basically, Superman is getting lonely, especially after finding out there really isn't anything left of Krypton after five years of searching.  That is the focus of this movie and not necessarily the high-action plot that many were looking for in this movie.  Instead, the writers took a closer look at the relationship between our hero and the ever strong Miss Lane and it really, really works.  They're crying together in the end, if that gives you any idea of what to expect - it's just a really strong love story between two soul mates that was acted out just beautifully.Next, I must say that this is probably one of the BEST movies I've ever seen in a long, long time (I've already seen it twice - you really need to because, although it's almost 3 hours long, it flies by pretty fast and there's a bunch of stuff you miss)! There's something for everyone in this film. As I said, it is a  GREAT romance, hands down. But that said, I think the men out there were expecting more of a "boy movie" with this film which it does deliver in some respects, but Bryan Singer does spend some time on the relationship between Lois and Superman. Something for the "girls" out there! It is extremely well written. As a writer myself, that just amazed me. Brandon Routh is absolutely awesome in the role of Superman and makes everything look so very easy (it's cool watching him fly - he just zips in and out almost completely unnoticed at times). This one is quite emotional and amazing with the tribute to the 911 tragedy in the first rescue scene when Superman appears to save the shuttle/airplane launch. Hearing and seeing the tears in the audience after that one was amazing. It was pretty funny seeing Lois faint afterwards too! Lots of different emotions going on in that scene! Plus, it was shot in Dodger Stadium so that's really awesome!Regarding the children - it is okay I think to take a child (not younger than five though - it gets pretty intense during the action portions plus, it's hard for them to follow) to this one (and I'm VERY picky about that). The PG13 rating is for some raucous language and one shot that could have been easily, easily left out - they have Clark Kent drinking a beer with Jimmie. Not much of a role model for young boys, huh? Other than that, this thing was incredible. Oh, another part in the movie that children might find upsetting is when Lex Luthor is trying to stab Superman with Kryptonite. Had to cover the eyes during that scene. It got pretty hard to take in some places.Otherwise, great, great stuff - a definite improvement over the previous episodes of the 80s. Routh's Superman definitely stands alone and one that just will be horrifically difficult to surpass. You definitely get goosebumps too when that rewritten theme comes on too. Golly! Highly, highly recommend this movie - can't wait to go out and see it again and get the dvd when it comes out as well! And, just for the record, I NEVER see movies twice. It's expensive enough the first time but when they're worth it, they're worth it and this one definitely is in my book. Thanks for a great film and in particular, one that is crafted and written very well. Highly recommend!
summary: A Review for the Moms and Dads, but especially the Moms!

reviewText: I really would give this movie 3 1/2 stars, but I figure what they hey, round up :)It's simple for me: when Superman was on the screen, it was awesome!  When it was Clark Kent?  Yawn.  The Clark kent scenes didn't have anywhere near the whimsical fun of the older movies.  Routh is a good actor, but he's no Christopher Reeve when it comes to playing the alter ego.  I would have graded the movie much lower if it hadn't been all Superman in the last 30 minutes.I enjoyed the tie-ins to the original movie, including lines spoken by Marlon Brando pulled straight from the first.  There were multiple "duplicate scenes" from the original that I enjoyed as well.  I just wish Routh had pulled Clark kent off better...As for Superman...  OH. MY. GOD.  The BEST thing they did was handle how Superman flies.  It was ALWAYS fast.  I mean FAST.  I mean "Faster than a speeding bullet" fast. ;)  I LOVED sitting there and feeling like I was being pushed back in my seat whenever we had an over-the-shoulder shot of Supes flying.  Excellent.  And the use of his powers always had what I would expect in a real superhero: routine for them but absolutely awe-inspiring for the common person.  They REALLY did a good job with the FX on this one.  Best Superman yet.So, I guess my title sums up my feelings.  When Superman was on the screen, I couldn't get enough.  When Clark Kent was on the screen, I'd had enough within 30 seconds.  That, and the "Savior" imagery was a bit much.  But whateva :)Bottom line: worth the price of admission :)
summary: Superman is great, but he's no Clark Kent
