reviewText: This should normally have been a five-star rating but there were a couple of things that irked me, despite some of the inconsistencies.  It was funny, the visual effects have been much improved since the last Superman releases, the acting was very impressive, and the story has been moved forward in a way that fans have been begging for a very long time.But for a Superman movie there was a lot of talk, talk, talk, talk, talk... while leaving everybody waiting for the next bit of action.  The action does come, but in small little pieces that leave you wishing for more.  This movie does not give Superman the screentime to really show off his powers.I was also irked by some of the changes.  For instance, the phrase, "life, liberty, and all that stuff?"  What, is the American Way not good enough anymore?  And some of the comparisons between Superman and Jesus Christ were a little unsettling.  Christ is the founder of one of the largest religions on this planet, DC shouldn't be getting such an ego comparing their comic book character to him.I got the High Definition edition of Superman and was very disappointed.  The picture quality, while better than DVD, was not as good as most of the other DVD movies that I've picked up.  The lack of high definition was very surprising considering the money put into this movie.I hope they make a sequel, there is still a lot to learn and see from Superman.  And now that film technology has caught up (and bypassed) the imagination of DC comics I hope they don't delay on making more movies.

reviewText: The Man of Steel was gone for over twenty years and he came back a grown-up.  That is the genius of Bryan Singer's Superman Returns, a film that both stands on its own merits and still manages to evoke the splendor of the Superman movies of the late 1970's.  The heart pounding special effects and super heroics are all here, but now they come packaged in a story replete with symbolism and a level of emotional depth that is not normally to be found in a summer blockbuster super hero movie.Make no mistake, this is not your father's Superman.  The Man of Steel, played by the able newcomer Bandon Routh, returns to Earth after having spent five years exploring the remnants of his dead home planet, Krypton.  Things have changed in the last five years though. The old crew is still there, with Ma Kent (Eva Marie Saint) looking after the farm in Smallville, Perry White (Frank Langella) editing the Daily Planet and Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington) snapping photos of Metropolis' favorite hero.However, you can never go home again, and the Last Son of Kyrpton is shaken to find that the love of his life, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), is an unwed mother of son, Jason, (Tristan Lake Leabu) with a live in boyfriend, Perry White's nephew, Richard (James Marsden).  Perhaps the only thing that has remained totally consistent is Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) who, having stolen Kryptonian technology from Superman's Fortress of Solitude, is planning to use it to create a whole new continent on Earth and sink the United States beneath the waves.The action scenes in Superman Returns are suitably impressive.  If the tag line to the original 1978 movie was "You'll believe that a man can fly," the 2006 version should be, "Now you'll really believe that a man can fly!"  The sequences are memorable, and one in particular, where Superman saves an airliner that is about to crash, will almost certainly have the audience out of their seats and cheering.However, the action is almost secondary.  Superman Returns is really noteworthy for its surprisingly complex emotions and symbolism.  Superman is still the square jawed hero, almost impossibly noble and virtuous.  However, he is also a deeply sad figure, lonely and denied his heart's desire by the call of duty to a world whose agony he can literally hear. He is, as his Kryptonian father Jor-El (Marlon Brando) tells him, "Raised among them but not one of them," and for all his mighty powers Superman is denied the simple pleasures of wife, family and ordinary human companionship.In this, by the way, Superman compares more than favorably to his Marvel Comics hero counterpart, Spiderman, who whines incessantly about the burdens of his powers and who does not hesitate to steel the girl from an honorable man. Superman bears his pain quietly and, though tempted, does not use his powers to take from ordinary men whom he could easily brush aside.  That nobility, with its overtones of Christian sacrifice, the screenwriters and Singer brilliantly capture in both dialogue and in splendid visual symbols.The acting in Superman Returns has not been compared favorably to the original Christopher Reeve movies, but this is mistaken.  Unlike the legendary Reeve, whose Superman was 100% the square jawed hero with a touch of irony, Brandon Routh plays Superman with far greater emotional depth.  This is the man behind the hero, powerful and noble, but also emotionally vulnerable, lonely, and even at times a bit frightened.  Similarly, kudos go to Routh for his portrayal of Clark Kent.  Somehow, in the 1978 movie, "mild-mannered reporter" got translated into "three-footed dufus." This was a ridiculous approach, and Routh here rights that imbalance, giving the viewer a much more believable Kent.Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane also surpasses Margot Kidder's shrill characterization.  Bosworth portrays Lois by turns as a loving mother and a tough career woman who, just beneath the surface, carries a bitter but conflicted resentment toward the hero who left her behind without saying good-bye.  Bosworth plays this shrewdly.  The anger and resentment are not just dumped out on the screen for the viewer to see, but rather seeps out in bits and pieces here and there.  Moreover, like the man that she truly still loves, she does not forsake another good man just to have the hero.  These are adults, they have made choices, and they live with the consequences.The other actors handle their parts with equal effectiveness and commendable skill.  Spacey's Luthor is not the clownish figure of Gene Hackman's 1978 portrayal, but is a genius with an almost frightening sadistic streak.  He was imprisoned for five years and he wants revenge.  There is humor, but there is also a chilling streak of pure evil. Langella's Perry White is not some boor bellowing in a newsroom, but is a cool professional who takes care of his people and his paper.  Sam Huntington's Jimmy Olsen is a likeable and very human person whose friendship for Clark is both boyishly endearing and deeply genuine.  Parker Posey is properly entertaining, and the presence of Noel Neill and Jack Larson is a nice touch.James Marsden also deserves special credit.  The character of Richard White is an especially tough one because it is easy to dislike him for standing in the way of the Lois - Superman relationship.  Yet Marsden shines in the part.  His Richard White is haunted by the possibility that the family he truly and deeply loves will be carried off by a god-like guy in a cape.  Yet he perseveres and becomes in a way the unsung hero of the film. He risks more than Superman because he has more to lose. Yet he saves Superman even when he knows that doing so may cost him what he loves most.Superman Returns is a surprisingly rich and complex movie, yet it manages to retain all the excitement of the typical summer blockbuster.  Superman's returned, and it's good to have him back.

reviewText: Movie will automatically play if you have not made a selection on Main Menu in 2 min., 50 sec.The story of Superman begins in 1938. He was heard on radio and seen in comic books.  In 1941, a brief cartoon of Superman was shown in the movie theaters with the voice of Bud Collyer as "Superman".Kirk Alyn made his appearance as "Superman" in 1948 with Noel Neill as "Lois Lane".Superman returned again in the form of George Reeves as Clark Kent/Superman in "Adventures of Superman" (1952-58).  Noel Neill returned as "Lois Lane" and Jack Larson began as "Jimmy Olsen".  George Reeves was growing tired of playing "Superman" and was upset that he would be typecast.  He committed suicide, June 16 1959.  This was dramatized in the motion picture, Hollywoodland (2006).The most poignant motion picture of "Superman" came in 1978 with Christopher Reeve (no relation to George) in the title role.  He had been an actor on the soap opera "Love of Life".Superman was a super-hit with Christopher Reeve and three more movies were made, Superman II (1980), Superman III (1983), Superman IV: The Quest For Peace (1987).  Supergirl was made in 1984.In 1995, Christopher Reeve was in a debilitating horse-riding accident that left him paralyzed from the neck-down. He needed the assistance of a breathing-machine so he could breathe.  With improvement, he was able to act again wheel-chair bound and even appeared in a couple "Smallville" tv-episodes.  Reeve died October 10, 2004.On August 14, 2004, Brandon Routh was told he was the new "Superman". He used to appear on soap operas, One Life To Live (2001-02), Port Charles (2001-02), General Hospital (2002-03).Superman has been away for 5 years to find out the truth about his birth planet, Krypton.He arrives back to Earth in the same way he arrived as a toddler.  His Earth-mother, Martha (Eva Marie Saint) comforts him on his return.  With his old job back as "Clark Kent" at the Daily Planet, he discovers that Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) was freed from prison because Superman wasn't around to testify.  Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) is now married to "Richard White" (James Marsden), her boss Perry White's (Frank Langella) nephew.  They have a young son.Also in the cast: Sam Huntington, Kal Penn, Kitty Kowalski.Noel Neill makes an appearance as Lex Luthor's mother.  Jack Larson appears as a bartender.The late Marlon Brando (Superman, Superman II) appears by the use of unseen archive footage.Note: Brandon Routh actually has brown eyes.  He wore blue contacts for the film.DVD is in full-screen. No audio commentary. No featuretes.  Available separately in Widescreen and 2-disc set.Other Superman programs:Superboy  1988-92) with James Haymes Newton/ Gerald Christopher.Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman (1993-97).Smallville  2001-11).Man of Steel (Blu-ray+DVD+UltraViolet Combo Pack)(2013).Batman vs. Superman: Dawn of Justice will be released May 6, 2016.
summary: Superman returns in the form of Brandon Routh

reviewText: SUPERMAN is back and its good to see him.  ROUTH is very appealing and has the look of our hero.  all the others:  LANGELLA, BOSWORTH and SPACEY are well cast.  story: new continent made from crystals and kryptonite with LUTHOR owning the new land and SUPERMAN returns from searching for planet KRYPTON.  STARTLING state of the art special effects(basically the plane sequence)--the rest are ok and you can tell the minatures in many of the scenes.  ROUTH showed his emotions well with likeable subtle nuances.  the length of the movie is a whopping 2hrs and 34 mins.  I love getting more bang/movie for the dollar but longer is not always better--they could have shaved a few mins here and there.  really nice interplay between lois and clark/SUPERMAN and it does make you like them even more.  LANGELLA and SPACEY do their best(SPACEY alittle more) in roles but I would have liked LUTHOR be aweebit more evil.  for some reason I really enjoyed SAM HUNTINGTON as JIMMY OLSON(his giddy innocence) and EVA MARIE SAINT as MARTHA KENT(his caring mum)---their roles were not significant, however-memorable at least to me.  you could tell alot from their role playing that they captured the essence of who they were.  lois has a child?-----is it with her husband or with SUPERMAN the twist is nice and you do wonder at times.  so, with all things said:  GOOD SHOW - go see it at IMAX theatre in your area.  this was a very good movie and all fans should go right out and see it.  I bought into it and can't wait for his RETURN again.  ps, even though we all saw this coming--in the credits they dedicated the movie to CHRISTOPHER REEVE and his wife DANA REEVES both who have recently passed on.

reviewText: It has been a long time since I've posted a film review online. I consider myself to be a film connoisseur even if my experience is limited to genre type pictures. The purpose of this review is to persuade you all to go see Superman Returns. It is one of the best films ever made (do not chew me out yet because this is only my personal opinion.) It was directed by Mr. Bryan Singer and stars Kevin Spacey, Kate Bosworth, James Marsden and newcomer Brandon Routh as the Man of Steel. It is as faithful to both the comics and Richard Donner's interpretation as you can get. It feels like a remake but it never manages to insult our intelligence and say it is, which is what I believe is the problem with other remakes of today.Routh as Superman. It was almost as if someone had reincarnated the late great Christopher Reeve. Routh had every little nuance, gesture, facial tic down to a tee. Also, the resemblance is uncanny. But resemblance is not enough; he brings to mind Reeve's iconic portrayal and also manages to make the role his own with small subtleties. Just like Christian Bale reinvented the Batman, Routh has brought us back the Last Son of Krypton while paying homage to the man who we all remember as the definitive version of the same role. I do not know if homage is a strong enough word for how Routh and Singer have honored Christopher and Dana Reeve. I know wherever they are, they are smiling.Superman in a new contemporary society. The world does not seem to have moved on much since his departure. There is still crime, despair, and poverty, so the world still needs a Superman. The only little inconsistency with this world is that Donner's original film takes place in the 70s and this film is obviously set in the 21st century. So that means either Donner's films will have to be retconned to have taken place in the not too distant future or, you know what? It really doesn't matter.Superman and Lois Lane's relationship. This is what carries the film and it does so effectively without being cheesy or contrived. It is an age old dilemma. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy disappears, girl moves on with her life but boy is still in love with her. Also, there is a unique plot twist that will totally blow you away and if you listen to internet spoilers, it may sound lame and campy. But Singer's direction and the way it is presented are so effective, you come out of the theatre satisfied.Spacey as Luthor. Now this performance seemed scary at first in the context that it looked as if Spacey was trying to copy Gene Hackman but he does not. This is Lex Luthor with the volume turned way up and it does not come off as over the top or campy. You really hate this guy and you wait in desperation for Superman to get his hands on him. His nefarious plot, while reminiscent of the 1978 original, is one of which only a Lex Luthor can think of.Ebert and the Hollywood System. Roger Ebert didn't like it. You know what? Screw Roger Ebert. For over 30 years the world has had this man's biased opinion shoved down our throats and I am sick to my stomach of it. How is he an authority on movies and has never made one? How can he tell Russell Crowe or Sharon Stone how to act when he has never been behind a camera? What makes his opinion the only one that matters? Jesus Christ! They act like he's God Almighty or something. See this film for what it is and not because of no talent hacks like Ebert telling you otherwise.Superman has had a rough road trying to get back on the silver screen since that 1987 flop, The Quest For Peace. It seems everyone that was attached to the project at one point or another wanted to reinvent Superman as a martial arts action hero weirdo like Van Damme or Seagal. You should read online some of the crappy ideas they had for a potential Superman film, everything from Matrix rip off fights to battles with giant spiders. Finally, here comes Singer who recognizes that such changes are unwarranted and that you have to keep the character true to the original stories and not some contemporary merchandise-sales-only-matter pop culture MTV machine (remember Batman & Robin).Singer's direction and the Musical Score. From the moment the Warner Brothers shield appeared to the end credits, I knew I was watching a Superman film. Aesthetically and artistically, the film seemed like Donner and Reeve were back together again in an all new completely original Superman story. Singer seems to have found his niche with this particular type of genre. I know in Hollywood, these type of movies do not get much respect because they are looked upon as too commercial and that they are for kids, but they are wrong. If they would look past the secret identities and corny getups, they would see the depth that pictures bring to the American cultural landscape. It is not about having super powers and saving the world, it is about holding true to your own personal principles and using supernatural means, even if they do not exist, to do so. Men like Sam Raimi, Christopher Nolan, and Bryan Singer seem to understand this and I hope they continue to put these masterpieces on the screen in the years to come.The main themes are borrowed from the great John Williams but the original themes make it seem like Williams was right there with John Ottman, who has composed a score that makes us once again believe a man can fly.The Final analysis. Along with X-Men: The Last Stand, this one of the few movies worth watching this year. Not because of the special effects but because of the depth of the characterizations and the lengths to which the filmmakers have gone to present us not only a great comic book adaptation, but also a great film. So I highly recommend Superman Returns to both the fanboys and the general move going audience. If Batman Begins is the best superhero adaptation to date, then Superman Returns is the second best. Side note: I know this may sound like an attempt for both franchises to be more pop friendly and fanboy pleasing, but I think Christopher Nolan and Bryan Singer need to start talking with one another. I know I don't have to say about what.

reviewText: I have been a fan of the Superman series since my dad took me to see the original in the theater back in 1978.  When I heard they were going to make another one, I was excited but at the same time, I could not imagine anyone else but Christopher Reeves playing the title role.  Yet, I was curious and my friends wanted to see it was well, so we all went ahead and saw it.  I want my money back!This movie is a joke.  The plot is weak and the role of Superman is out of character.  There are siuations that Superman is in which he, the actor, acts and does things totally out of the character of Superman.Lex Luther, played by Kevin Spacey, is a joke as well.  The simple truth is he simply is not believeable.  He does not act ruthless, nor does he seem to have a true hated for Superman.  He shows he would like to destroy him, but not with the zest that Gene Hackman showed.  In the original, it was clear that Lex Luther wanted to kill SupermanIn the final analysis, it's obvious that this plot really does not make much sense at all.  A lot of things are not explained and there is no real climax.  If you are a Superman fan, I'd strongly recommend seeing the first two installments made back in 1978 and 1980.  And for you die hard Superman fans, you may be interested to know that Warner brothers is going to release a special edition of the fist 4 film when this one is released.  They are also going to release Richard Donner's version of Superman 2 which never has been released.  Donner was fired when the film was almost complete and the producers hired Richard Lester to take over and basically remake the movie.  It is rumoured that Donner's version of Superman 2 is far better than the one released.  As for this movie, the best part was during the credits where they dedicated the movie to Christopher and Dana Reeves.  Christopher, you are the real Superman!!!
summary: Christopher Reeve's may be rolling in his grave

reviewText: "Superman Returns", written by Michael Dougherty & Dan Harris; directed by Bryan Singer.A long time ago, two Jewish boys from New York created an immortal figure in pop mythology, who has come to define the genre - the very state - of being a superhero.  But maybe that's a little too far back.About thirty years ago, a team of filmmakers decided once again to tell that story - the tale of Superman, "strange visitor from another planet, with powers far beyond that of mortal men".  I saw "Superman - The Movie" when I was thirteen, and was delighted.  Like many of my favorite movies, "Superman" was everything I wanted it to be, and some things that I didn't even know I wanted yet."Superman" was also one of the first superhero comics that I read, and I responded strongly to the story's iconic qualities.  The first film (not counting the movie serials) preserved and expanded on those  elements.  In the forty years since his creation, Superman had gone from being an American icon to a world citizen, the 1978 movie ending with him soaring high above the earth.Which brings me to last Friday,  when I saw the latest version of the orphan son from the planet Krypton.Here, Superman's role has expanded yet again, this time to the scale of a Christ figure.  I suppose the parallels could always have been made, and here Mr. Singer and his writers don't hold back.  When his spacecraft again plummets down to the Kent family farm, Martha draws Kal-El from the wreck in a tableau meant to evoke Michelangelo's Pieta.  The film is rife with comments and images meant to evoke a divine quality - Luthor calls Superman a selfish god and later stabs him in the side; some of the flying stances mimic the crucifixion; and so on.It's a natural connection to make - a powerful son from the heavens is sent to lead, rescue and inspire us - but even taking Superman's considerable iconography into account, it's a rather outsized and unwieldly one.  I'm assuming that Mr. Singer intended it to give shading and dimension to the story, but instead it cloaks the proceedings in a veil of gloom.Superman represents something very specific to me, and while Mr. Donner's film captured it, I think Mr. Singer's misses the mark.  Superman is a product of the '30s - a figure of unabashed optimism emerging from the shadow of the Great Depression; the friendly, dependable policeman on everybody's block.  While I'm sure there was corruption then as now, Superman at that time represented the best that Americans could hope to be - powerful and just.  He was the other, the immigrant, but he was a part of us, too.  Christopher Reeve's goofy charm managed to make that very squareness sincerely work through its own merits.  In the current version, we're treated to the type of grey brooding, weighty symbolism, and life trade-offs better suited for Spider-Man or Batman.  But for me, Superman's never been that sort of hero.It's difficult for me to believe that he'd be so fixated on his past that he'd so thoroughly neglect his present as he does in this film, abandoning his adopted world and his true love to discover what we knew all along - Krypton was destroyed and he is the only survivor.  There's not much to motivate this, except that his home planet's former location was determined.Naturally, Lois (Kate Bosworth) is heartbroken, and while he's gone (it takes five years to get there and back, though it's not clear to me why Superman needs a spaceship at all) she moves on, marrying a clear surrogate (he's even a pilot, for goodness' sake).  She's written her article on "Why We Don't Need Superman", winning a Pulitzer in the process, and had a child.  This is what Superman (Brandon Routh, an eerie echo of Reeve's performance) returns to - while most of the world gleefully rejoices, Lois wants little to do with him.So mighty Kal-El, for all his fame and power, becomes a mopey ex-boyfriend.  When he's not involved in heroics, he's hovering over Lois' home, peering inside with his X-ray vision.  It's sympathetic for an ordinary guy, but it's more than a little creepy coming from an omnipotent super-being.Fortunately, Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) is at large, and once again up to mischief.  This is all Superman's fault, since he didn't show up to a hearing (again, why not hold off the Krypton trip until the guy who tried to detonate two nuclear warheads and drop California into the ocean is behind bars?).  Luthor high-tails it back to the Fortress of Solitude and steals all of the crystals that educated Superman on his maiden voyage to Earth.  It turns out that they're capable of far more than we realized (but, assuming that Superman knew that, left them unprotected for quite a while), and Luthor builds a far larger version of his previous plan.These parallel threads weave on throughout the story, but not before one more big surprise is unveiled.  The origin of this twist is extremely murky, and its emotional payoff somewhat limited, raising more questions than anything else.The Christ parable abruptly stops when the story requires a larger sacrifice to be made.  Superman has already lost Lois with no way to truly reunite with her; and the hero of the biggest tentpole picture of the summer can hardly be killed.  Lois changes her tune and decides 'we' need him after all, but since there's so little chemistry between them, it hardly means much.  The plot, Luthor notwithstanding, basically ends in a romantic stalemate.This is not to say that the film doesn't have its pleasures.  Most of the cast is fine, with Routh and Bozworth at least dispelling my concerns about baby-faced reporters.  The only true squandering is Parker Posey's moll - she's neither daffy sex-doll nor snappy spitfire, so it's hard to see why Luthor keeps her around.  The special effects are naturally on a grand scale, the technical portrayal of Superman is especially vivid, convincing and impressive.The Richard Donner "Superman" was a huge inspiration for the director, and it clearly shows.  Much of the film - from the acting styles of the cast, the faux-slit-scan credit sequence, the savvy blending of the retro-Daily Planet/Smallville/Americana/Clark Kent garb in a contemporary setting, the return of the John Williams score, right down to the labeling of a Kryptonite meteor - labors mightily to revive the feelings that many of us had in 1978.  Yet as a whole, the grafts don't take, not really. Mainly because, at its heart, it's not much like that film at all."Superman - The Movie" made me wish I was Superman.  "Superman Returns" makes me glad I'm not.

reviewText: Being shelved, fought over, re-written and passed on by three CEOs, over 20 producers and countless writers, the wait was finally over when Brian Singer decided to take the reins on rebooting the Superman franchise.  The only person to survive the whole process was Jon `former hairstylist to Barbara Streisand-the movie must have a giant spider' Peters, whose heavy handed and outlandish approach to the character was probably one of the main reasons the movie never got made in the 90s.  Look him up, check out Kevin Smith's `An Evening With...' and you'll understand what I mean.  He represents the worst of Hollywood's worst producers who think they know what people want in doing massive re-imaging of classic characters.  He would make remake John Wayne into a Lawyer and Marilyn Monroe into `Barb Wire' if he had his way.But I digress.  His name is most likely on this movie simply because he has been involved from the beginning.  Thankfully Brian Singer, who proved his worth with the first two X-Men films, brings high end quality to the film and the story.Five years have past since the story of Superman 2 (Superman 3 & 4 thankfully have been graciously and shamelessly ignored/forgotten) and the Man of Steel returns to Earth after searching for remains of his home world.  At his return he find things have moved forward without him.  Not all in a good way either.  He finds the world has changed quite a bit, most due to 9/11 as he flips through channels and sees the news reports.  He also finds that Lois has moved on, having a child and a fiancé.  This lends to a great human element of Superman; did he ever think about how the people of Earth would move on while he was gone?  Did it occur to him that Lois wouldn't wait forever?  The humanistic aspect of this discovery lends to good dramatic elements.  Superman doesn't give up so easily on Lois and she obviously still harbors feelings for him.  Although she's deeply ticked at him for leaving without saying goodbye, so she keeps her distance.On the other side of the coin, Lex Luthor is released from prison, ironically because of Superman not showing up for the Appeals hearing.  He immediately begins planning his next scheme.  Kevin Spacey is on the money as Lex, giving an efficient performance.  Lex is determined to be the mastermind he is and he doesn't waste time talking about out loud or gloating when he could be furthering his goals.  He is intelligent, vicious and surprisingly likable.To further comment on the casting, I have to say I have mixed feeling about Brandon Routh.  Generally I think he's excellent.  He plays both sides of the character as well as Christopher Reeve did.  As Clark Kent his goofy antics to cover suspicion are actually even more subtle and more endearing.  As Superman, he's a little less convincing.  He doesn't have the presence that Christopher Reeve did, but you want so much to believe he is Superman that any doubts you have are just washed away with his likeability.  His Midwestern values ooze from his persona, just like Reeve.  The few doubts I have may be there only because that was the Superman I grew up with.  Newcomers won't make those comparisons.  Even so, no one can deny that Reeve had a greater physical presence and his eyes had a piercing quality that just can't be duplicated.  I was more impressed with Kate Bosworth.  Going in, I knew nothing about her, but once I first saw her on the screen I wasn't impressed.  But as the movie went on, I realized she had the grit and venom spitting down.  She was a tough woman reporter who had been scorned, and despite her finding love again with someone else, the moment Superman shows up, she kicks up the venom spewing a notch.  By the end, you're opinions of her have changed, but she really hasn't.  She (Lois) is still a bit bitchy and not totally over the whole being scorned thing.  However, Kate is a bit young to have gone through everything they talked about AND have a kid AND be as world weary as she is.  These are all just nit picks though, I still enjoyed watching them both.  Routh and Bosworth have good chemistry, which is important considering the chemistry between Reeve and Margot Kidder was so great.The plot line is not too far off from the first, but still original.  There is no doubt that so many aspects of the movie are an homage to the Richard Donner/Christopher Reeve films made over twenty five years ago.  Singer throws in just enough of the back story of those films to continue on here.  Composer John Ottman certainly ignores his own pride and integrates the popular John Williams theme into his own score, stitching together the past movies with this one even more.The action scenes are great in this one although I would have loved to have seen more super-feats (rescues, stopping criminals, etc.), there was an entire montage of those in the first movie and with so many similarities why not do that too.  There is a great shot that is a tribute to Action Comics #1 where he is putting the car on the ground.  Fans will see it.  Overall it was an incredible movie with great heart and soul being used to revive one of the worlds greatest heroes.  Welcome back Superman.

reviewText: I was able to see this film over the holiday weekend. I've noticed a lot of people were hungry for this film to come out and ended up somewhat satisfied with the product.  "Superman Returns" is a competent movie, generally very well produced, directed and cast. But it didn't quite gel for me. I thought it dragged at points, as Superman got bogged down with pining over Lois Lane instead of saving the day. I thought the dialogue just wasn't sharp enough to sustain these heavy-handed emotional scenes; what sort of catchphrase is "I'm always around," anyway?Here's what I did enjoy. The flight scenes were beautiful; Superman cut a very majestic figure as he soared across skylines and stars capes. The set design was great, too, creating a modern feel with hints of the Art Deco style I associate with Superman. And I appreciated the performances of Spacey, Bosworth and Langella. Routh had a curiously small role, especially as Clark Kent, so I had trouble judging whether he was wooden or actually good at playing a modest hero.Here's what I enjoyed less. Luthor's plan simply didn't interest me. I found the whole notion of growing a giant crystal island very surreal and not too threatening. Also, he poses a fairly boring threat to Superman. If Luthor's got Kryptonite, Superman is helpless; if he hasn't got Kryptonite, he's helpless. These two legendary antagonists can never really meet on equal terms. Thus, most confrontations between them must inevitably be one-sided.I also had a mixed reaction to the CGI effects. Some were wonderful, and others looked artificial despite being very detailed. I so very much wanted to love this film but sometime Hollywood studios have a way of systematically destroying every decent franchise they get their hands on. In spite of my mix emotions of the movie, it's far from being horrible. It's just not great...like it should have been.
summary: Superman return to us with a mild storm.

reviewText: Since others can do a much better job relating the story, I will give my take on the film only from a singular perspective--the Christian messianic take on Superman as 'savior'.First off, I enjoyed the movie. As one who remembers the original Lois Lane and Jimmy Olsen from the TV series, it was nice to see them again in cameo roles.The special effects rock--literally. The quakes, shakes, (near) crashes will pound you, and these were well-done. I will not discuss the plot involving Lois, Clark, Lois's husband and son, etc. Other reviewers can do that. But suffice it to say, this is a great story.The film--over 2.5 hours long--is two movies. The first half is the typical (and nicely done) Superman fare. Unlike many, I did not feel the opening sequences lagged. They tied up loose ends, provided retrospection and the acting (all the way through) was great.My only disappointment was the made-to-happen `bonding' between Lois's husband and Clark Kent. Not disappointing because it happened, but because it didn't. It came close at times, but never really materialized. What a shame.The second half of the film was Messianic--to the point of going `over the top' in some instances. This is not a complaint. It would be hard to believe however, that all of this was unintentional. Even the names of the main characters contain the moniker 'El', which is a Hebraism for 'God'. Initially, like Christ, Superman comes to the world unrecognized, unappreciated, and rejected (Lois's "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman" wins a Pulitzer Prize).In short, there are crystals (belonging to the destroyed world of Superman's father), which are stolen by the villain Lex Luther. He seeks to create his own 'world' by propagating these crystals in the sea, but he underestimates the proclivity with which the crystals grow. These ever-growing masses even fuse with the kryptonite Luther uses to encase them as they are 'planted'.Superman must save the world from the rapidly growing crystals. But to do so, he must succumb to the power of the deadly kryptonite. He must face the enemy in order to defeat it. In short, we see the hero suffering, dying, departing to the 'underworld', rising from the dead in glory, and finally ascending into the heavens. The messianic overtones (or undertones) are as obvious as the twice-repeated "...the father becomes the son; the son becomes the father", and the father's words "They (humanity) only need the light to guide them. I sent you, my only son.". Christ, of course, is the 'Light of the world'. One can hardly miss the father to son: "...you will never be alone", much as Christ claimed co-eternity with His Father.For those seeking theology in the film, it is not easy to miss the crystals as 'sin'. As Satan perverted that which was meant for good from the Father's world, so Luther steals the crystals. Both the crystals and Satan's deception in Eden involve that which was to make one 'wise'. Too, as evil lurked in that first garden with Adam and Eve, and confronted Christ in Gethsemane, His garden place of solitude, so the evil Lex Luther stole the crystals from Superman's place of solitude.The prevalence and permeation of sin in the world is the pictured in the crystals' growth which becomes virtually out of control. And embedded within is the deadly kryptonite--the sting of sin--death. Superman, in seeking to be the savior, is seemingly defeated by Luther (Satan) and the cruel mistreatment at the villain's hand is reminiscent of Christ's torture by the Romans, and in a similar vein, the torture of Aslan by the White Witch in The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe.At last, Superman is stabbed by Luther with one of the deadly crystals, and, like Christ, "tastes the sting of death and sin", though He is innocent. There is a descent into the deep 'abyss' of the sea, (although this is not the final death scene) reminding one of Christ's descent into the belly of the earth. But Superman will eventually return and rid the planet of this evil by lifting the entire thorny-appearing, dark  crystal 'world' skyward (Christ being `lifted up' and bearing the sin of the world), and separating it forever from the earth he loves.In the end, the empty hospital room where Superman dies screams 'empty tomb!'. Like Christ, even his clothing lies neatly folded beside him. But the hero gloriously ascends from death into the clouds after reminding those who would miss him: "I'm always around", much as Christ's "I am with you always".I won't give away the scenes and plot twists that made this film enjoyable, but it's impossible to miss the messianic overtones.

reviewText: Roger Ebert gave the first Batman 2 stars and he's wrong again with Superman Returns which he also gave 2 stars. It's a great ride and it brings back the kid in you just in the opening credits and hearing the John Williams classic musical score. Superman returns after 5 years of looking for any piece of Krypton that he can find. He returns to find Lois engaged to Perry White's son played by James Marsden (X-Men) and with a kid as well. He finds himself needed again just when he's settiling in. Lex Luther has an evil plan to basically turn Earth into Krypton in a world where he'd be the leader.This movie is 10 times better than Superman 3 and 4. It's not better than part 1 or 2 but it's right up there with them at least. Brandon Routh may not be as good as Christopher Reeves as playing Clark Kent or Superman. However he is the best Superman next to Reeves. Routh's Superman looks like he popped right out of the comic book. He may not have Reeves' charm but he still makes a very heroic Superman. As for playing a bumbling reporter, he needs to work on that a lot before the next movies. Ebert was way off though when he said he barely had any lines because they probably dind't know if he could act. Routh has a good part at the end where he delivers the lines that were once said to him by his father. He does it well too.Kate Bosworth's Lois is more vulnerable than the kind of Lois we're used to. I mean she gets knocked around violently by one of Lex's bodyguards. You know the Erica Durance Lois in Smallville wouldn't take that [...]. Erica Durance is a very good Lois and it's sad that Smallville is only interested in pushing Lana in our face constantly and they don't  know how to use Lois. Anyway Bosworth still looks the part at least and does give us a different Lois even if it's not a better Lois.Kevin Spacey is excellent as Lex Luther, he basically gives us an older version of Michael Rosenbaum's Lex in Smallville. Gene Hackman was a great Lex Luther too but his was a little too whacky. Spacey makes a great ruthless and scary Luther and it's one of his best performances in awhile. Parker Posey is also excellent as his partner Kitty. She livened up movies that weren't that good, like Scream 3 and Blade Trinity. Here she's finally in a good a movie and has really good chemestry with Spacey. Hell they have better chemestry than Routh and Bosworth who don't have Reeves and Margot Kidder chemestry.One problem with the film is that....Lois Lane and Clark never work together. She never even wonders why Clark isn't around when Superman is around. It is funny though when Lois and her fiance joke about how Clark and Superman have the same height and built. Plus although Spacey is a great Lex Luther, I am sort of Lex Luthered out. I know part 3 sucked when it tried to have someone other than Luther as the villian. But I'd love to see Darkseid in a Superman movie for once . They need someone evil with powers like part 2 had Zod. I'd like something like that instead of just Luther as the villian again. It's still hard not to get into this movie though or get excited when you hear the John Williams score.
summary: One of the best Superman movies

reviewText: Let me begin by stating that the original Superman film with Chris Reeve is one on my dearest memories from childhood. From the majestic opening credits to the uncanny way they made his flying believable (the pre-CGI days..remember those?). Verisimilitude is what Donner called it..making the unbelievable seem totally grounded in reality. Seeing that film with my Dad in the Christmas of 78 will be etched in my memory for a long time. Why, you ask? Not because I was 9 and the world seemed innocent and fresh and not because every kid loves a superhero flick. It was because Donner completely NAILED that character. He took what would seem to be a sappy, boy scout, goodie-goodie character seem respectable and completely admirable. This during the jaded and disillusioned 70's. We rooted not only for Reeve, the wide eyed young actor in his first major film role, but for Superman and all his "truth, justice, and the American way" idealism. Even during the post-Vietnam skepticism that the country was still tasting.That said...enter Bryan Singer. Here's a guy that made one of the best crime dramas ever put on celluloid (The Usual Suspects) as well as taking an obscure, although having a rabid fan following, comic book and making two films that not only NAILED the nature and spirit of the source material, but made it accessible for even the most clueless of film-goers. I'm talking, of course, about X-Men.If ever I had faith in a director to bring back the Man-Of-Steel to a new generation of movie watchers and possibly recapture the magic of the original Donner film, he was just the guy to do it. This is what makes this review all the more painful because he did just the opposite. Not only did I find this film to be a complete insult to the Superman mythos new and old, but I found it to be melodramatic dribble.Singer manages to suck you in at the opening credits with Brando's voice overlooking the planet Krypton as we know it to be in the original film. Then the planet explodes in a way far more dramatic than the original and it is stunning to watch. The credits roll over John Williams' rousing anthem and the audience is entranced. I almost had tears as I watched with my 11 year-old son as it reminded me so much of my experience with my father. After that..it's all downhill.Superman is poorly written as a bit of a creep. Part voyeur (he uses his x-ray vision to spy on Lois at her boyfriend's home), part narcissist in the prideful way he tells Lois the world needs him, and worst of all..part deadbeat dad. If this is a spoiler to you, then you have shown no interest in the film to begin with. Yes, Superman had fathered a child with Lois (see Superman II) and then just took off for 5 years when he discovers that scientists believe Krypton still may exist. This after apologizing to the president for being away for so long at the end of Superman II. This is supposed to be a direct sequel?? Man..Singer and his boys failed to do their research.Another thing that got on my nerves was the way Singer injected Superman with a Christ complex. Okay Brian..He's the only son of Jor-El and was sent to Earth to save us from ourselves..We get it!!! Having him fall to the Earth in a crucifixion-like way was a bit over the top. One more example of Hollywood's disdain for Christians. I'm sure I'm also not the only one who noticed Perry White's inability to say "..and the American way". It just come out as "Does he still stand for truth, justice, and all that other stuff..?". One more example of Hollywood's hatred for American pride and values.Some of you may be wondering.."Why so upset over a stupid comic book movie?". I'll tell you why. Superman is the icon and the standard by which all superheroes that have followed him owe a tremendous debt to. He got us through the darkest days of the depression and World War II. We flew with him during the cynicism of the Vietnam era and the trashed sensibilities brought forth by the "flower power" generation. Even through highs and lows in popularity, he has always been someone to look up to in a metaphoric way. Someone good, honest, and unwavering in his morals and standards. Now in an age of conflict and uncertainty, when this country could use Superman the most, Singer belittles him and turns him into a man more damaged than anyone we could possibly know.Apart from Routh and Spacey, the film was poorly cast as well. Lois looks like she's fresh out of college, much less the mother of a five-year-old boy. That after having been around the block a time or two. Bosworth is still in her mid to late 20's and simply can't pull off that character. Langella was a dull Perry White. There was no fire to that character whatsoever. Worst of all...Parker Posey. The mighty indie queen has fallen.In a nutshell..if you're reading this Mr. Singer. You should simply walk away from Superman all together before you do any more damage than you already have.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can not describe in words how much I love this movie. It was the perfect sequel to Superman and Superman II, starring Christopher Reeve, and I grew up watching those movies. It had to be just right, done perfectly, or I would have despised it.Brandon Routh played Superman the way Christopher Reeve did, and did so well that at times it made the hair on the back of my neck stand up, because he portrayed the character to such a tee. With Christopher Reeve unfortunately out of the running to play the role, *I think Routh was the only one who could fill his shoes. He paid tribute to Reeve very well.Lex Luthor's character was a little edgier and angrier than in the original movies, but that is doubtless explained by 5 years' imprisonment, and he wasn't so over the top that it completely distorted the original character. Lois Lane's character was well-portrayed by Kate Bosworth. Although she seemed a little malnourished, she had spunk and I actually liked her in the role better than Margot Kidder.As a film-score fan, and one who grew up humming John Williams' original Superman theme, the score also had to be perfect, and John Ottman not only retained the theme, but also worked himself to death to ensure that the entire film, from beginning to end, had an A1 score. I hope that John Williams was proud of Ottman's work, because he should have been.Word has it that the Superman franchise is on indefinite hold because of legal battles over rights and royalties. It is also rumored that WB was so unpleased with the film's nearly $400 million gross (?!) that they might take the franchise in an edgier direction in the future. That would be a horrible mistake... Superman is not, and never has been, dark or frightening. It is not Batman Begins, The Dark Knight, or anything even remotely like it, and it never should be. This film was the only way it could have been done, and kudos to Brian Singer for reviving a legend.
summary: The Only Way It Could Have Been Done... A Fantastic Sequel!

reviewText: Never mind the plot rehash, it's been rehashed through 150 reviews already, and the "Superman" genre was never about plot anyway.  The Man of Steel has been around saving the planet since 1939 and he's back, after a five-year hiatus, to do more of the same.  Nothing much new there.  But there have been some interesting character changes and two of them are noteworthy.First of all is Brandon Routh as Superman.  Even before Christopher Reeve's tragic accident, he had run his course in this role; the films had gone downhill after the second movie and hit rock bottom in "Superman IV".  But Reeve was so perfect in the part; he looked exactly how everyone ever imagined Superman must look like, and one could only wonder if anyone could ever fill Reeves boots in this sequel.  But just as Richard Donner used a then-unknown Reeve in "Superman", Brian Singer wisely cast another unknown in this film, and Brandon Routh is a very good Superman indeed.  He looks every bit as much the character as Reeves did and his acting in the part is just as good.  He doesn't need to fill Reeve's boots; he wears his own Superman boots very well.The second important character change is Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor.  I thought Spacey was great in this role, much better than Gene Hackman.  Hackman played Luthor for laughs; Spacey plays the part for pure evil menace, much as Superman's creator intended.  Spacey plays Luthor to the hilt, gleefully pulling every trick in the book to destroy his nemesis and almost succeeding.  He and Routh are two great reasons to go see this film.The other actors give creditable performances, especially Frank Langella as the editor of the Daily Planet; I liked him better in that role than Jackie Cooper.  The plot is predictable; we know Superman will save the day, so what else is new?  What blows us out of our shoes in this production is the jaw-dropping, eye-popping experience of watching it in IMAX-3D.  The special effects are so incredible in IMAX that you feel like you're literally falling out of your seat right into the screen.  There's almost no way to describe it; it has to be experienced to believe it.  I'm still wondering, though, why Singer chose to shoot some, but not all scenes in 3D, which means you have to keep putting on and taking off your 3D glasses as the scene changes demand, but maybe watching the whole film in 3D might be too much of a sensory overload.  All I can tell you is that once you've seen this movie in IMAX, you'll never want to see it in any other format.  No, I'm not waiting for the DVD.  A DVD would be a flat letdown after seeing this movie in an IMAX theater.What "Superman Returns" adds up to is a fun movie.  There's been a lot of serious analysis of Superman as some kind of Messiah figure in this film, saving the world and mankind from the evil machinations of Lex Luthor and his dastardly henchmen.  Please.  Superman has never been other than a comic book figure and he still isn't.  But he's great fun to watch, and the IMAX production is a mind-blowing experience you won't forget in a hurry.  Make tracks to the nearest IMAX theater and prepare for the ride of your life.Judy Lind
summary: It absolutely, positively, MUST be seen in IMAX!

reviewText: Where to start? It is simply speaking phenomenal. Bryan Singer was already at the top of my list for director/producers that I admire. He's stepped it up here.If you didn't already know, the movie assumes Superman: The Movie and Superman II occurred. Superman III and Superman IV did not. It is not a reinvention of the character or story. It's a continuation. If it has been a while since you've seen the first two movies, you'll benefit by re watching before you see Superman Returns. You won't miss anything if you don't have time though. It simply adds to the experience.John Williams' Superman theme music remains the Superman theme. I'm pleased they didn't try to create a new theme for Superman, because Williams' theme is iconic. While creating a new score for the Superman Returns, the composer, John Ottman draws inspiration from Williams' original score and you'll catch reflections of that throughout the film. It's nicely done and I'll be purchasing the CD as soon as possible.All the effects are wonderful. The special effects in the action sequences are breathtaking. They kept me on the edge of my seat. But I was also impressed by the less noticeable special effects such as the city of Metropolis. It looks like a real city. It's big. It's sprawling. It's old and new. Unlike previous movies, Metropolis is more than the gritty bustle surrounding the Daily Planet. It has added depth and dimension to the character of the city.Brandon Routh is the new Superman. He draws inspiration from Christopher Reeve's performance as both Superman and Clark Kent (more noticeably Clark) but he isn't simply mimicking Chris Reeve. He makes it his own. (The film is dedicated to Chris and Dana Reeve toward the beginning of the end credits.) I was overwhelmed when he first appears in The Suit as Superman. And charmed by his bumbling Clark Kent. The physical change he makes between the two is amazing, with little more than a change of posture and removal of the glasses. You can believe people would look past Clark if they speculated on Superman's alternate identity.I initially wasn't sure of Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane but she works in the role. It didn't help that I kept seeing pictures of her as a blonde and while the trailers showed her in character and brunette, it wasn't enough to gauge her character. But I actually believe in her Lois Lane more than I could in the original movies, both as an investigative reporter and romantic interest. The chemistry between this Lois and Superman is strong and the chemistry between Lois and her fiance is also good which strengthens the emotional conflict of the film.Kevin Spacey is perfect as Lex Luther. In the earlier films, I felt the comedy aspect overshadowed Lex's power and potential menace. Kevin Spacey gives that to Lex. Like his role in Usual Suspects, he disappears in to the character and despite being easily recognisable you don't see Kevin Spacey as Lex...you see Lex. He is powerful. He is menacing. He is a threat. There are comic touches to him. You can't have Lex Luther on the screen without those touches, but the balance is different. Instead of slapstick, it is ironic humor borne out of the truth of his intent...a much darker comic element.To touch on a few of the other characters: Sam Huntington is exactly right as Jimmy. He's geeky and charming in a funny sort of way. His Jimmy fits well in the history of his character. It was wonderful to see him get to have a small scene played against the original Jimmy, Jack Larson. Unless familiar with the George Reeves' Adventures of Superman series and what Jack Larson looks like today versus then, you wouldn't realise the underlying significance of the scene so it mainly adds another element for the hardcore Superman fan. The same can be said of Noel Neill, the original Lois Lane in another small part. Frank Langella is a fantastic actor and does Perry White proud. I would like for him to have had more time onscreen but there was so much going on it would have been difficult to make the film longer just to do that. And since all of the actors are committed to two more Superman movies, I'm sure we'll see more of him. (I just hope Bryan Singer agrees to do the next two films as well.) Another significant character in the form of Jor-El also returns and I'll just say I am happy with the way they did this. I also liked Eva Marie Saint as Martha and look forward to some expansion of her role in the next film. Despite her limited time onscreen, she gave an honest performance that added layers to the time she did have.Superman Returns is a fantastic movie.While I doubt it will become a classic in the way of the original movie, it honors, enhances and expands it and the second film. It deserves to be part of the Superman mythology, as I have no doubt it will, and I'm looking forward to the sequels.Superman is back! And in a big way.

reviewText: Superman traveled to his distant home after scientists on Earth had thought that they had discovered the far-away planet with a telescope.  When Superman got there, all that remained was a graveyard.  He came to the final conclusion that HE is all that was left from his civilization.  With this is mind, he had no where to go but back to Earth.Unfortunately, in the mean time, the sinister Lex Luthor discovered the strange, almost magical crystals that came from Superman's planet.  He leaned how to harness them for his own evil ends.  He also commandeers the recordings that Superman's deceased father had created, and listens to them in order to understand the extent of his new found powers.  He creates a continent, a continent that will cause global flooding and kill billions.  He steals kryptonite and makes it a fundamental piece of the new continent so that Superman cannot interfere!Meanwhile, in Superman's personal life, the lovely Lois Lane is engaged to marry and now has a son.  Superman now has a forminable enemy and a larger void in his personal life.  The movie shows how Superman uses his wit and attempts to get around the problem of a Kryptonite laced continent and still defeat Lex Luthor.Aside from the main plot that involves an evil new continent and love for Lois Lane, Superman also goes back to his old ways of saving lives and fighitng crime.  There are several scenes that show him dominate and subdue common criminals.  He defeats things such as machineguns and catches falling innocents.  There is also a somewhat-related scene, when he tries to save a spaceship and and airplane.  In this particular scene, there are great special effects.If you are somewhat attached to the original Superman, you will be pleased, as those who did the casting did a pretty good job in selecting characters to this sequel.  The Special Effects are really off the hook, especially during the daring plane rescue.  The plot is solid enough to keep you interesting throughout this fun movie.  I would definitely recommend this movie.
summary: Entertaining, good special effects, solid plot

reviewText: Superman Returns is set in the same world of Christopher Reeves' Superman. It is a continuation from the previous movies. (This is unlike Batman Begins which completely rebooted the Batman series.) There are good and bad parts about this movie.The Good:For one I think Brandon Routh did a great job playing Superman. He sounded and looked like Reeves. Parker Posey was very funny as Lex Luthor's sidekick. The cinematography and effects were decent.  The movie paid homage to the original movie like the beginning credits. The original John Williams Superman theme song was used throughout the movie. Overall, the movie was entertaining enough to recommend.The Bad:Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. She just didn't impress me. Margot Kidder was a lot better and more likable. Also, I didn't care for Spacey as Lex Luthor. I thought he was not as funny as Gene Hackman. I also was expecting more from the movie itself. I thought Bryan Singer who directed the first two X-Men would deliver the best Superman movie. I hoped Superman Returns would be to Superman what Batman Begins was to Batman. This was not the case. Singer says he was just establishing the characters in this one and he will go "Wrath of Kahn" on the next one.

reviewText: I was skeptical when I found out that they were planning to do another movie on Superman.  First of all, I thought why would they want to continue the sagas without Christopher Reeve?  I remember watching Superman in 1978 and Superman II in 1980 and thinking that nothing else could ever top those movies (especially with the disapointment of Superman III and Quest for Peace).  I thought that they have done enough and just leave the series alone.When I went to see this one, I was happily suprised to find that they used the music from the original sagas and that they didn't try to outdo the original series but pay homage to them and tell a different account of Superman.  Brandon Routh is a great Superman (unfortunately it will leave him typecast for the rest of his career), Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is excellent (and she is so SEXY!), and Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther was great (wouldn't it been fun to see Gene Hackman as Lex Luther Sr.?) Anyways, great special effects, a good plot the story, and believeable characters.  I think Christopher Reeve would of been pleased with this rendition of Superman.Recommended!
summary: Good movie and a worthy addition to the Superman sagas

reviewText: Along with fellow director Sam Raimi, Bryan Singer ought to be regarded now as the best American director of films based on comic book heroes. Having enjoyed his two fine filmed adaptations of the "X-Men" comic books, I had little reason to expect anything worse than yet another decent film adaptation from Singer. With "Superman Returns", Bryan Singer pays ample homage to Richard Donner's great 1978 "Superman" film and offers a superb cinematic epic in what promises to be a successful re-launch of a "Superman" film series. Much to my surprise, Singer's riveting new film isn't nearly as dark as his two "X-Men" films, but instead, remains true to the optimism and light comedy which Donner conveyed successfully on screen. Indeed, "Superman Returns" should be regarded as the immediate sequel to the first two "Superman" films starring the late Christopher Reeve, since it is set approximately five years after the second (1980) film, relying once more on John Williams' memorable "Superman" theme (courtesy of young film composer John Ottman, a frequent collaborator of Singer's) and a brief, digitally-realized cameo appearance of Marlon Brando as Superman/Clark Kent's father.Much of "Superman Returns" success is due to a fine script written by Bryan Singer's "X-Men" collaborators, Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris, and excellent acting from a truly memorable cast featuring distinguished veterans like Eva Marie Saint ("Martha Kent") and Frank Langella ("Perry White"). Although others have unfairly compared Brandon Routh's portrayal of Superman/Clark Kent to the late Christopher Reeve's, I found his portrayal quite credible, without trying too much to be quite evocative of his famous predecessor's brilliant portrayal. Without question, the best acting honors goes to actor Kevin Spacey, who brings a disarmingly devilish twist to Lex Luthor, transforming him into a more malevolent villain than Gene Hackman's splendid portrayal. Parker Posey is almost as fine too as Lex's femme fatale companion Kitty Kowalski. Actor Kevin Huntington steals nearly every scene he appears as the earnest, if naive, photojournalist Jimmy Olsen. I also enjoyed Kate Bosworth's portrayal of Lois Lane, but I will concede that hers isn't nearly as romantic as Margot Kidder's. And I didn't see nearly as much of a romantic chemistry between her and Routh (or with James Marsden, who portrays her fiance, Richard White, Perry White's nephew) as I recall seeing between Kidder and Reeve in the first two "Superman" films.Bryan Singer's direction is superb, though "Superman Returns" isn't as visually exciting as his two "X-Men" films. Still there are plenty of superb action sequences, beginning with Superman's breath-taking rescue of an out-of-control U. S. Air Force Boeing 777. All of these action sequences had the audience's rapt attention during a screening I saw yesterday afternoon. Singer's splendid "Superman Returns"  is undoubtedly a vivid, well-executed re-launch of the Man of the Steel as a potential cinematic franchise along the lines of the James Bond and "Star Wars" films. Having enjoyed Singer's "Superman Returns", I look forward to the prospect of a possible revival of the "Star Trek" movie franchise, which Singer may be at work on soon.

reviewText: What I like about this Superman is he captures that awkward brilliance that was Christopher Reeves - even kinda looks like him!But whereas the movie starts strong and makes us feel very exhilarated, the latter half of the movie falls flat.Gene Hackman played a Lex Luthor that you would despise yet also laugh off and laugh at. He wasn't a nemesis that you would fear, like the new Batman's Heath Ledger's Joker. In the first Christopher Reeve's Superman, it was all about Superman, and Reeves carried the whole film. For some reason, I didn't feel Brandon Routh's Superman carried the film, and worse yet, I didn't feel Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor had that Hackman magnetism.I guess in the end, although this is the "New," it's just not the same - it doesn't carry the same magic feeling.Hopefully the next one will delve deeper into the character, but just not on the superficial level.To me, the most "human" film of all the superhero movies is the Spiderman trilogy, and I think since Superman can be a really deep character to explore into, hopefully it will develop into more of that direction, than the usual Hollywood blockbuster movie devoid of any real story and character development.I enjoyed it, but it's not on the same level as the new Spiderman and Batman (even the new Edward Norton's Hulk has better character development).

reviewText: After all the "Smallville" and other stuff, having the Man of Steel back on the big screen (like he really should be) was quite a treat last summer.  And now, the DVD let's you see it all on your big Plasma, hi-def screen at home.Much of what's written below compares, inevitably, Brandon Routh to Chrisopher Reeve.  Well, let's face it:  if you want Christopher Reeve badly enough, nobody is going to satisfy.  I thought Brandon did a wonderful job with the role.And I was, if anything, disappointed with Lex.  The guy playing him has been around, and has been celebrated as a great actor.  Here, he seems to sleepwalk through the role.  Kevin, you're not going to maintain your reputation this way...Finally, though, the true Achilles heel of this version is the writing, not the acting or even directing.  It should have been four stars, but the writers felt like they had to go for the shock value somehow.  I did not like that, and felt that it compromised the whole effort.Overall, though, it was one of the best movies of 2006, for sheer watchability if nothing else.

reviewerName: John S. Harris "The Voice of Reason"
reviewText: Good bonus features with this DVD.  Some of the behind-the-scenes footage dates back to the time before director Bryan Singer was even attached to the project.Routh is wonderfully understated as Supes/Clark.  He brings a quiet grace to the role.  Reeves' performance was very comic-bookish by comparison.Singer tosses in some references to his favorite films in "SR".  I betcha a nickel that Singer is a fan of "Capricorn One" -- there is one element in "SR" that is too similar to a scene in "C1" to be coincidental.  Even his production company is called "Bad Hat Harry", a phrase from a line in "Jaws", a movie he confesses to loving (as many many many of us do).Actually, as much as I enjoy actor Kevin Spacey, I thought his performance was rather unremarkable.  Competent, sure, but not particularly thrilling.  At least he didn't go too far the other way and take it too far over-the-top.  That would have been worse.I also bet ya that even though Noel Neill played the dying widow Gertrude in the film, her dialogue was dubbed over by Margot Kidder.  Betcha a nickel on that too.

reviewText: For a description of the plot, etc., read other reviews.  I just want to give a few thoughts on this movie...Superman Returns (2006) is a solid Superman movie sequel.  I saw it in the theater when it came out.  The original Superman movies with Christopher Reeve were good (at least the first two were).  While I don't think Superman Returns has quite the depth of these movies as far as story, plot, and characters, I consider it a pretty good movie.  Kevin Spacey was good as Lex Luthor.  I thought Brandon Routh did very well as Clark Kent/Superman.  He looks so much like Reeve in this movie.  Some people say he gave too many nods to Christopher Reeve, but whatever.  I didn't care for Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane.It was great to see Eva Marie Saint in this movie.  It was also great seeing Frank Langella.I've never been a big fan of Superman in general (comic books, movies, etc.).  To me, Superman is just some immortal guy who has super powers.  He's a character that's harder for people to relate to compared to, say, Batman.  Batman is mortal and he trained to learn his fighting techniques.  He's easier to relate to.I recommend seeing Superman Returns.

reviewText: In a movie overpopulated with miscasts, Brandon Routh was a delight as Superman. Sadly, he wasn't given much to work with. The movie itself was anything but a delight, as it didn't pass my "must make sense" meter.I like to watch films that would be classified as fantasy (and this would) with people who don't intrinsically understand fantasy. What I mean is that if a little green man pops up behind a tree and does something magical, the person I'm watching the film with should understand what the little green man's purpose is at some point prior to the conclusion of the film. If they don't, then I think the movie or story failed to establish itself appropriately. One friend of mine, who is a scientist, reads the books that win Pulitzers, yet loved the Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings films. To me, his assessment of whether the filmmakers did what they needed to do to make fantasy reality is a good one. That said, I've disagreed with him more than once, and the word idiot has surfaced. When it did, that never went well with us. <grin>That said, I believe that fantasy needs to make sense. But, you say, it's fantasy! It doesn't need to make sense!Not so.More than any other genre, fantasy has to make sense, because it has more to prove. You question this? Think on Gollum.Here we have Lex Luthor, taking a crystal from the Fortress of Solitude and encasing it a hand-made cylinder of Kryptonite (what a guess!), and launching it into the ocean, using it to try to create a continent that somehow - magically perhaps? - creates a habitable continent that will not only destroy all of the United States with the exception of the western states (YIKES...is Bryan Singer really a friend of Ann Coulter?) but will have its own mapped states - for indeed, the continent as Lex showed it looked a bit like Australia, chopped up into "regions".Sigh.As to the miscasts, Lois Lane looked more like a porcelain doll, and her son - and I feel horrible for saying this - just couldn't be a product of his parents, regardless of what angle they're playing. Lex Luthor was a brainless wimp who resorted to stupid bully tactics when faced with a "kryptonited" Superman. For someone smart enough to encase a crystal in kryptonite, he certainly showed himself for a fool. His thugs - well, some of his thugs didn't even have muscles. One appeared in a movie that served as a White Castle commercial.My guess is that since Gene Hackman played Lex Luthor in the 70s, they wanted another good actor to play Lex Luthor. The problem with that line of thinking is that when they tried to pick a good actor in the 21st century, they settled on an average actor: Kevin Spacey.One who wasn't miscast, but also wasn't given much material: Parker Posey. She's always a delight in whatever she does. I just saw her in "For Your Consideration", and she took what she was given and did a terrific job with it. Here, she did the same. Again - she wasn't given much.Even though I felt this was a disaster of a film, I'd like to see another. Certainly not from the same production team or screenwriters, but there is something in Superman's "mythology" to mine: "The Death of Superman". In the early 1990s, Superman faced a foe capable of astonishing destruction, and that series of comics sold more for DC than any other. The sequence needs to be brought to the screen, and I believe Brandon Routh is the right Superman to play the part. With CGI where it is (again, think Gollum or anything from The Lord of the Rings that wasn't human), the timing is right.Let's see it.And let's have the studios give Brandon Routh another chance with better material. He did a terrific job with what he was given.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sure, it was fun to see Superman on the big screen again.  We've all been waiting for it.  And yes, the movie had some entertaining areas, but really I think it fell short of what it could've been.  A few weak spots:- Too many scenes of flying around.  Yes, we get it: it's cool if you can fly and look at the pretty scenery.  But honestly, by this point I think the novelty of Superman simply flying Lois around has worn off to the point where it doesn't merit a 5 minute flight scene with no dialogue.- Characters seem a bit wooden.  Routh and Holmes as Clark and Lois: well, they weren't bad, but really there was no fire in their relationship.- As many have pointed out, Superman picking up an island made out of kryptonite really doesn't make sense.  Sure, you could say "But he's Superman! He can do anything!", but you have to stick to the rules of the movie.  If simply being near kryptonite makes Superman double over in pain, there is no way he could pull off the island-lifting scene, regardless of how long a sun-bath he had.- Lex Luthor: eh...  I like Kevin Spacey and all, but he just wasn't diabolical / genius enough.  Really, he should've been more competent an adversary for Superman.- And lastly, one must question the morality involved in Superman attempting to break up Lois's happy marriage.  Not exactly heroic.So there's a few areas which bothered me.  Now I know the majority of people loved the movie, and I'm not saying it was terrible, but I just feel it could've been so much more.

reviewText: The long awaited return of one of the most popular and beloved superheros finally comes back full cirle.Superman after being gone for 5 years to visit his home planet comes back to the one world he knows that is always in chaos-earth.His affections towards Lois Lane have'nt ceased,but his departure has left her  bitter.She has since "moved on" and durring that time had a child,very possibly his own?Old flames never die and it isn't long before Superman and Lois Lane aren't involved,and not always on romantic terms.His nemis Lex Luther is at it again with the plan of world domination by means of realestate.Luther steals crystals from his home world found at his Artic fortress and Luther soon puts them to the only use he knows how,not only as a means of destroying continents,but also to kill Superman once and for all.Be ready for a great story telling,characters,excellent acting,action and spectacular special effects.Brian Singer hits another home run with another comic book adaption as only he could.Well worth seeing and owning,this was of the few 2006 summer blockbusters that lived up to its hype and will certailnly be joining my ever growing collection of great films.
summary: Superman makes for a solid return.

reviewText: Superman Returns(2006) made Superman popular again in 2006, but the film itself was criticized for being "boring, sappy, too long, disappointing, etc.". Everyone from Kevin Smith to The Simpsons to Epic Movie(2007) has poked fun of it. Superman Returns is a decent movie and it's been unfairly judged. Superman(Brandon Routh) has spent five years in space looking for remains of Planet Krypton. Back on Earth, everyone has moved on without him. Lois Lane has a son and a fiance. Superman must regain his place in the world and stop Lex Luthor(Kevin Spacey)from another diabolical real estate scam.Director Bryan Singer really put his ego aside to make the film. He also includes references to Superman rip offs such as Puma Man(1980) and Supersonic Man(1979). He also references a Turkish Superman clone made in 1979(Superman smiling through the back window of a car)! We get to hear John Williams' theme music from Superman The Movie(1978). Adventures of Superman cast members Jack Larson and Noel Neill make cameo appearances. The scenes where Superman saves people on a damaged airplane and where Metropolis is shaken by an Earthquake are exciting! Superman Returns does have pacing problems and some flaws, but it's still a solid superhero film.
