reviewText: There is a reason that the 1978 version of Superman is a classic.  It stands against the test of time.  Christopher Reeve definitely made you think that he could fly.  Subtle body movements were more than enough to make you feel Superman in flight.  He also captured both Clark Kent and Superman, giving each of them defining characteristics that made you like and care about them, even though they were, technically, the same person.  Back in 1983, they tried to re-make Casablanca.  It isn't hard to understand why it failed.  When a movie is deemed a classic, it's virtually impossible to make it again.  Like a work of art, it can't be duplicated.And that was the first and biggest mistake of the writers and filmmakers on Superman Returns.  They simply should have made a Superman of their own rather than try to copy and extend the storyline from the original films made over 20 years ago.  Christopher Nolan understood this when he decided to finally make a good Batman film (Batman Begins).The writers probably thought they were paying tribute to the 1978 classic when they borrowed similar plot lines and even used the same dialogue in several places in this film.  You'll recognize many lines and parallel plots to easily make the connections between the '78 version and this film.In the 1978 version, Lex tries to sink part of California to increase the value of the desert land he bought.  In this version, he attempts to create his own land, using stolen Kryptonite technology and wiping out the eastern half of the United States.  You can't help but say, "haven't we already seen something like this before?"To be fair to Brandon Routh, you simply can't fill the shoes of Christopher Reeve.  However, Routh makes Superman much too wooden.  He doesn't give much indication of anything.  He lacks the charisma that's needed to play both Superman and Clark Kent.  His facial expressions are nearly void of emotion or feeling.  Christopher Reeve was a Juliard trained actor.  He literally immersed himself in his roles, including Superman.  Routh also doesn't disguise his voice as Clark Kent.  And no one can make the connection?!?  Reeve gave Kent the charm of a bumbling Cary Grant reminicent of the Grant's film "Bringing Up Baby."  Supposedly, Superman Returns is a continuation from the original Superman films.  If so, why does Clark Kent no longer disguise his voice?  Also, you just don't get the sensation that he's flying.  Part of the problem with this is that there aren't enough close-up scenes of him when he's flying.  The writers and director also never devoted enough time to the characters of Clark and Superman to where we feel a connection with them.Kate Bosworth is simply awful as Lois Lane.  In fact, I don't think anyone has portrayed her worse.  Bosworth seems almost lost in how to portray the "tough" reporter of Lois Lane.  Even Margot Kidder furnished Lois with a "go get'em" attitude.  Bosworth plays Lois like a wallflower.  Plus, there is no chemistry between Routh and Bosworth which is the pinnacle of this story!  The love connection has always been about Superman and Lois Lane.  Again, they attempted to copy the romantic Superman/Lois flight as Superman takes Lois for quick ride into the night.  It doesn't work.Kevin Spacey has his moments as Lex Luthor when he's almost good as Lex Luthor.  He attempted to stick with Gene Hackman's performance.  The scene with him beating on Superman when he's being affected by kryptonite is good.  Lex is supposed to have a savage side to him.SPOILER ALERT BELOW!The back story is also not convincing enough.  Superman travels back to Krypton to find out if it is, in fact, destroyed?!?  After Jor-el tells him during his training that Krypton is gone, it's hard to believe that he would need confirmation, even if astronomers claimed to have seen it.  If Superman remembered Einstein, as Jor-el taught him about Einstein's theories of relativity in the '78 version, Superman would have realized that light from "Krypton" would only now be seen from Earth, and therefore, Krypton is not really there anymore.Also, the part with Superman having a son just doesn't fit at all.  When and where was this to have supposedly happen?  Again, if this is supposed to be a continuation of the original Superman films, the only time "Superman" slept with Lois Lane was in Superman II, and even then he was mortal.  Plus, the timing doesn't figure into it.  The writers tried to sell this "bit" but instead of trying to make it somewhat credible, it ends up being ludicrous.The kryptonite is also handled poorly.  Superman's powers are literally drained from him, making him even weaker than a normal person.  If you recall in the 1978 version, he couldn't even take the chain off from around his neck when Lex put the kryptonite on him.  And suddenly, in this film, with a fragment of kryptonite stuck in him, he's able to lift a land mass the size of a small country out of the ocean and into space?!?  It isn't likely or believeable, nor are we given a plausible explanation about how he could do this. Even in "Smallville" when Clark is exposed to kryptonite, he can barely move.Many of these problems could have been fixed simply by making a new and different Superman, rather than continuing where the previous films left off.  It would have been that simple.  I mean, they did manage to give Superman a totally different costume (the worst Superman costume ever designed).The special effects were first-rate, but this day and age, special effects aren't enough anymore.  We want a good story with good, believeable characters, and this film simply doesn't have either one.
summary: Re-hash of Similar Plot Simply Doesn't Fly

reviewText: Doing my part to balance out the insane ravings of a bitter lunatic.It was good to see Superman fly again.Brandon Routh was amazingly good in the role of both Clark Kent and Superman, up to and including some cute moments of bumbling a-la Christopher Reeve.  The effects were beautifully done, and Kevin Spacey is the best Lex Luthor ever to grace the screen, one moment charming, and the next utterly terrifying.  The score was masterful, I couldn't stop smiling when that familiar theme began.In short, a wonderful movie, and a wonderful tribute to the man who made us believe he could fly . . . and an appropriate passage of the torch to the next man to wear the cape.

reviewText: No offense to Brian Singer because I really did enjoy the X-Men movies, but I still don't understand who decided that re-making Superman was a good idea. Even more obvious in my head then Micheal Keaton is Batman, Christopher Reeve *is* Superman. It took the phenomenal talent of Christian Bale to shift the idea of who The Batman could be and make me believe it. How could any less be expected of the next actor to fill Reeve's blue tights.What Christopher Reeve did was to create two separate and individual characters who just happened to be played by the same actor, and although we occasionally see them merge together for a moment or two, brief reminders that Clark Kent is Superman in disguise, it's that dedication to playing them as total polar opposites that makes Reeve's Superman iconic.Unfortunately, as hot as he is, all Brandon Routh did was to remind me that he isn't Christopher Reeve. He looked the part well enough and mimicked Reeve's performance close enough that I didn't throw popcorn at the screen, but there was nothing that made me think, oh, yes, he is Superman. I was entertained, but mostly I just thought of how much better Christopher Reeve was in the part.Kate Bosworth never even came close to Margot Kidder's Lois Lane, but then I never expected her to and so there was no real disappointment. It looked like they tried to age Bosworth into the part, which only made her look like a teenager playing dress-up. I didn't believe her as a mother for one minute, but doesn't necessarily require age to make believable. Acting chops, however, would have helped.The rest of the cast was mostly negligible. I didn't care for the attempt at externalizing the love triangle between Kent, Lois and Superman by introducing James Marsden as Lois's capable, hunky Superman-esque fiance. He was, I think, meant to represent a melding of the two characters and I found that extraneous. Because of the type of film it was, I wasn't expecting Lois to leave her fiancé for the Man of Steel and without at least the hint of that possibility, we loose a lot of narrative tension.Gene Hackman continues to reign supreme as Lex Luthor. Kevin Spacey did nothing to convince me of otherwise. I did, however, adore Parker Posey as Luthor's Pomeranian carrying girlfriend, Kitty. I was initially reminded of Miss Tesmacher in the original Superman, but that didn't last for long. Parker's ditzy, emaciated brunette was just screwball enough to make me forget (or forgive) her similarities to Miss Tesmacher.Overall, I was surprised that I didn't hate Superman Returns, that I was just entertained enough to watch it til the end and was even invested in him recovering, like we knew he would, from the Kryptonite poisoning (How he managed to lift that giant coral reef of Kryptonite and hurl it into space, I will never understand, especially considering how it was COVERED with Kryptonite AND he had Kryptonite fragments still in his body -- but oh well, handwave, as they say).Maybe if there hadn't been so many successful re-inventions of the Superman mythology then I would have been more satisfied with the movie. I don't, for example, ever compare Smallville with the Superman movie franchise, or Tom Welling with Christopher Reeve. In my mind they are two different things. Same goes for differences between the films and the cartoons (Animated Series and Justice League). I can only lay blame at the feet of a movie that invoked a superior film without successfully reimagining it into something new and fresh.

reviewText: I was worried about Superman Returns when after 20 minutes it failed to excite me. Then after Superman decides to rescue Lois on the plane things really become hot. The new actor who plays superman really has both Clark/Superman down. He really managed to portray the angst and sadness of the alien being which is superman without being a self-pitying sad sack.Lois was another matter. At first, I found the new actress for Lois a little annoying. She was fairly plain and her hair was always flying everywhere. It was difficult for me to believe she was a star reporter. She just didn't have any 'presence' or 'poise' when giving her interviews. I am glad she was less abrasive than her predecessors, but would've liked to see her look a bit more believable. She looked like an extra from Charmed, rather than poised confidant reporter. Perhaps this could be fixed with a better wardrobe, stylist, etc. Oddly enough though, the actress grew on me. While I don't think I could ever see the comic book Lois as a "Mommy" I ended up liking this Lois more than the previous one. Go figure.Jason was adorable, and I'm not a big fan of little kids in movies. They kept his lines to a minimum and he was perfect.Lois new beau was great. I'm a HUGE fan of Marsden, so I was pleased to see the actor introduced as the 'third' corner of the love triangle. I was glad he had a larger role, and that the character was not minimized to make Supes look good. He shown particularly in the plane scenes and the scene on the boat towards the end.The only downside of this film, I think was Lex. He was just too goofy. His sidekicks weren't serious. I'd like to have seen a more diabolical and calculating Lex, rather than the cartoon "I'm so evil" villain we were treated to. I guess I liked the Lex from Smallville so much, its hard to go back to the over-the-top version. Perhaps Lex was done this way to add some comic relief, but it seemed a bit flat considering the serious undertones to the film.There were a few false notes. I didn't care for the humor involving the Pomeranians...And Lois rebounding in the plane and walking around afterward was a little too much.5 Stars. A compelling, intriguing film. Must see!!!

reviewText: Superman is one of the best superheroes of all time. So most fans were awaiting a return, right. Yes. But Superman didn't need to return with this film. Before you buy or rent this film, you must know it is one of the weakest comic book based film I have seen. It is not as bad as Fantastic Four, and it doesn't even come close, but it does not give superman justice.Superman fans were excited when they heard the director's name: Bryan Singer, the one who spawned the first two X-Men films. This film bombed based on expectations. With a budget of around $215,000,000, it only grossed $200,000,000. It lacked the $15,000,000, which dropped the budget for the follow-up to $175,000,000. You might ask, why did it kind of bomb?The storyline is spectacular. Superman returns after five years to see Lois Lane with a child and engaged, writing articles for The Daily Planet, bashing Superman. It also involves Lex Luthor trying to take over the world once again, only this time he is trying to wipe out the United States to make a new continent. The film starts off very slow, and the first seven minutes is just credits alone. Then it becomes cliched in superhero films. The film only has three major action scenes: the plane crash, the bank robery/car antics, and the world taker over, the last thirty some odd minutes of the film.The film is gorgeous, don't get me wrong, but it doesn't have the heart that Superman has. Brandon Routh is an excellent Superman, yet Kate Bosworth is a heartless, boring Lois Lane. Kevin Spacey is a fun, just fun, Lex Luthor, but he is not that evil. Parker Posey plays Lex Luthor's femal sidekick, adding humor that was actually funny.The film is promising during the action sequences, but it becomes boring when Superman and Lois Lane are having their "Why did you leave" romantic moments. THe only shocking thing about Superman Returns's plot is (SPOILER WARNING---SKIP THE REST OF THE PARAGRAPH IF YOU DO NOT WANT TO FIND OUT!!!) Superman has a son, Lois Lane's son, which it is obvious from the second time you meet the child.I thought Superman Returns was going to be a fun superhero adventure, like Spider-Man 2, yet it falls short to be a mediocre cry for a return of Superman. The film didn't have the heart it needed to succeed. It is gorgeous, and if it were a film about nothing, it would deserve an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture, but it is a film about Superman, a boring film at that.
summary: Superman Didn't Need to Return with This Film

reviewText: Have no fear,it's finally here! No,not Underdog The Movie,but the LONG awaited return of the Man of Steel,Superman!Bryan Singer has created in Superman Returns a masterpiece thatfans and moviegoers won't forget anytime soon.Taking place afterSuperman II,Superman Returns gets the series back on track and makes us remember why we love the Man of Steel in the first place.Here is my review of this wonderful film.(includes minor spoilers)Scientists have found the remains of the remains of Krypton,soKal-El,aka Clark Kent/Superman(Brandon Routh),makes a journey tothe remnats in the Kryptonian spaceship he arrived in from thefirst film.He is disappointed that what he finds nothing of anyvital significance and flies back to Earth.When he returns,theworld has changed:five years have passed and the world has learned to move on without Superman.The girl he loves,Lois Lane(Kate Bosworth),is now a mother,is engaged to be married to theeditor of the Daily Planet's nephew(James Marsden,"The X-Men Trilogy),and has written a award-winning article called "Why theworld doesn't need Superman."After visiting his mother(Eva Marie Saint in a wonderful performance),Clark returns to Metropolis in order to get his job back at the Daily Planet.Nobody knew he was gone,except Jimmy Olsen(Sam Huntington,who gives the film's best performance),who is overjoyed to see his friend return.While the two are taking a lunch break,Lois is on a plane where she is taking part in aspace shuttle launch when all the technology fails.Clark watchesthis on the television and knows it's time to return as Superman.After stopping the plane(the film's most amazing scene),Lois is reunited with the man she loves and is reunion of mixed emotions.Meanwhile,the technology has failed because of a certain bald villian.That's right,Lex Luthor(Kevin Spacey)has been released from prison and is launching another scheme asonly Lex can.Now,Superman,who is slowly winning back the respect of the people of the world,including Lois,must stop Lex before Lex achieves world domination.To sum it up,this is the most fun,you will have at the movies this year!The acting is wonderful.Kevin Spacey chews up the screen as Lex Luthor.He is like Gene Hackman in the sense that he is funny,but he is also very driven in this movie to destroy Superman and to fulfill his plan of world domination.Parker Posey is Kitty,his female accomplice and she has several good moments in the film.James Marsden is also very good as Lois finace,Richard.Eva Marie Saint is not in the film very much,neither is Frank Langella as Perry White,but are both very good.No need to worry about Sam Huntington as Jimmy;he is the best actor in the movie.And now the two leads:Kate Bosworth is a very good Lois.Not only is she really attractive(sorry,had to put that down),but also acts like Lois would today.She is very good in this role and I hope she continues the role in the next couple of movies.And finally,Brandon Routh.Brandon Routh is a very good Superman and I think he is an absolutley wonderful Clark Kent.He picks the mannerisms of Christopher Reeve(Rest in Peace),but he adds something to the roles,especially as Superman.He WILL win over fans and I hope to see him in this film's sequel.Other positive aspects of the film are the action pieces,the visual effects,and the score.The action is the best there has ever been in a Superman film.Superman stopping the plane,saving the city,and all the other action scenes are wonderful as well.The visual effects are great.Superman finally flies the way he always should have.You will be very impressed as he see not only Superman using his flying abilities,but also his heat vision,super breath,and his many other abilites as well.The score is great as well.Wisely using the classic John Williams score,the film also uses new music from John Ottman(X2:X-Men United)and it goes very well with the original score.Two thumbs up with the above mentioned.As good as the film was,it's not perfect.It does have faults,but they are minor.The first problem was at first some of the scenes felt out of order near the beginning of the movie.However,it was important to the plot and once I thought about it,the movie began to flow much better.Second,Brandon Routh,Kate Bosworth,and Kevin Spacey are great,but Christopher,Margot Kidder,and Gene Hackman are the ones I grew up with,so it felt weird seeing these great actors in these roles.But they are so great that they eventually win you over with their performances.And third and finally,the movie is similar to the first film,but to me,this is a much better movie than the first because the characters are better and the plots  for Lex's plan and the Superman/Lois Lane scenes are far better here as well.So overall,Bryan Singer has created another comic book movie masterpiece that will join with Batman Begins,the Spider-Man Movies,the X-men Movies,the first two Supermans,the Blade movies,Batman:Mask of the Phantasm,and the Crow as one of the best comic book movies ever made.Bryan Singer truly made a film for the fans and you can tell he is a fan himself just from watching the opening credits.You will love this film.I am a even bigger Superman fan now after seeing this film and hopefully everyone else who sees the film will feel the same way.Superman is back! Enjoy the ride!

reviewText: Bryan Singer has true talent for bringing comic book characters to the big screen!  He proved that with the first two X-Men films.  He definitely does NOT disappoint with his Superman debut.  Singer wanted an "unknown" to play the lead, in much the same way Reeves was chosen years ago to play the caped crusader.  Brandon Routh is perfect.  He is respectable to what we, the audience, expect from Superman, a bit of a tribute to Reeves in his looks and demeanor, but he also applies something new to the role as if we are seeing Superman for the first time ever.The special effect scenes are not too over the top, so this doesn't become an action-packed thriller that leaves you stunned but bored.  The first real big scene involving the airplane will have you hooked. The story line is solid and it is what it is, picking up right where the last Superman movie left off practically.  Clark comes back and is trying to gel back into the scene at the paper.  Lane has a kid and a steady boyfriend.  And boom...Superman is back to save the country from Lex, played by Kevin Spacey.  There is nothing "too new" about the story, except for the actors themselves, so SM fanatics can definitely appreciate it.  Clips of Marlon Brando as SM's father are even used as a tribute to the early films.With as many over-the-top, action packed, cheap thrills, bad acting, and poor story lines for movies that are cluttering up the big screens these days, Superman Returns definitely saves the day for us moviegoers.  You have to appreciate this film for its new edge on the comicbook take, but also for the good old true fashion values it brings to the overall theme of Superman the character that we've come to appreciate throughout the years.Christopher Reeves would be proud! And Routh is signed on for at least two sequels, so there is more brilliance to come!

reviewText: Superman Returns is a strange movie to watch.  Gone is the square jawed linebacker sized hero.  Instead, newcomer Brandon Routh gives you a Superman that is more like Michelangelo's David: an almost sylph-like figure, that floats beautifully above us all, watching, protecting.  In doing so, the movie conveys, intentional or not, a great loneliness and vulnerability in the Man of Steel, but also, always, the sense of Duty.  Essentially, I liked Routh's version of the great hero.  But the rest of the casting is not very good.  Spacey and Langella, two really fine actors, are miscast.  They never seem to capture the elusive "whatever" that director Bryan Singer was able to capture with Routh.  Spacey is viscious at Lex Luthor, but he has no style.  Luthor has to have style, but Spacey gives us a villain that is just a dead eyed figure belonging to another genre: noir. Langella seems like he's on medication, and not the hyper editor we should expect.  Only Parker Posey, as Luthor's associate and babe Kitty, seems to remember that this is a story based upon a comic book.  Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is also miscast.  There were times I felt most of the supporting actors were sleepwalking through their roles. The story itself is somewhat incoherent, but I chalk that up to the film being something of an intended re-introduction (and grab bag) to the characters and elements of the Superman story.  However, despite all of these missteps, weirdly, the film works.  I guess, perhaps, because we all want a Superman up there, watching, protecting us all. And Superman Returns does remember that One Essential part of the story, and returns to it, smartly, again and again.

reviewText: I remember seeing Superman IV in the theaters when I was six, how there were so many people swarming all around, how there was excitement. Clearly it was a shoddy movie, but to a kid you just can't buy that kind of palpable movie madness.Now I'm as old as my parents were when they saw the very first Superman, and I've got to say this must be what it felt like. I think Bryan Singer is fast becoming one of the most respectable directors in Hollywood, and what he did with this movie--on a far, far grander scale than either of his X-Men movies--merits SOME kind of award come Oscar time.We all know the story--Kryptonian boy comes to Earth, saves man from the foibles of archnemesis Lex Luthor, woos Lois Lane. Singer and Co. decided to have this movie pick up after Superman II (wise move) but you never really get a jarring sense of chronology--no General Zod references here. Instead, Supe has just returned from a nearly five-year journey to see if anything remains of his homeworld; alas, the answer is no.What's strange is that him being gone is such a small deal when it comes to the overall movie. But that's okay; there's plenty more fantastic things to keep the average moviegoer and Superman afficionado happy. What I love most about this sequel is that so much of it feels like home--Brandon Routh has moments where he looks exactly like the dearly departed Christopher Reeve, and his voice is dead-on most of the time. He quotes several lines from the first movie to great effect. Kate Bosworth as Lois isn't as quirky as Margot Kidder but she still can't spell, and she does the best job I've seen in a long time of playing the "strong female" role without ever drawing your attention to it.The plot also feels familiar--Superman spends a night righting wrongs across the world; Luthor AGAIN gets hold of that Adis Ababa kryptonite, and Supe AGAIN falls prey to it; but there are intriguing elements dealing with Fortress crystals that take Luthor into land-grabbing madness like we've never seen.The special effects are superb, of course; you can't spend almost $300 million and get it wrong! Here is where I thought Singer might overdo things, but his restraint is commendable. He allows Routh to do all the old Superman things and yet they don't feel aged at all. Singer was concerned with how to entertain a generation where flying is no longer the spectacle it once was, and yet, watching the movie, it's hard to believe that any kid, no matter how jaded, could scoff at what's on screen. The movie is that well done.Don't let detractors fool you. This kind of movie only comes along...once every thirty years or so.
summary: A Superman we can root for

reviewText: Despite having modern special effects and an awesome Lex Luthor, played by Kevin Spacey, Superman Returns disappointed me more than a little.First of all, Superman stands for, "Truth, justice and the American Way," not "Truth, justice and all that stuff." All that stuff? All that stuff? What kind of anti-American person wrote this movie? Look, if you hate America that's your business, but don't corrupt Superman!Second, Superman has an out-of-wedlock child with Lois Lane! Then when he finds out about this child, he doesn't even *attempt* to talk her into making things right by getting married. What sort of morals are you trying to teach our young people in this country with this horrific example of making babies with no thought of marriage? Technically, Superman and Lois Lane never actually did the big nasty because of time travel. Did the director even watch the previous movies?Supposedly, Superman went on a five year trip to the destroyed planet Krypton, just because he "had to see it." Had to see it? Who goes on a five year trip solo just to see something that isn't there anymore? Been to Mount Saint Helens lately? What did he eat? Drink? Did he share this miraculous new interspace travel with the rest of the world so they could explore the galaxy? Oh, he was too busy sightseeing to consider that.There are just too many holes and inconsistencies with the story here, and Superman, greatest of all heroes and role models, has been corrupted. Someone make a better movie, please!
summary: No American way? A Superman with absolutely no morals?

reviewText: As a big fan of Superman movies, this movie, which is actually a sequel to the original Superman II, does not disappoint. The special effects are great (which is expected) and the storyline invokes a sense of empathy to the main character. This makes the portrayal of superman more "human" with feelings and emotions that are common to the rest of humanity.The acting of Brandon Routh as Superman is great but not outstanding. Nevertheless, the casting of this actor as Superman is most appropriate. It makes the audience feel that they are being transported back in time to 1978 when the first Superman movie came out and Reeves was the lead actor at that time. I most definitely felt a sense of nostalgia when I compared this movie to the first two movies of the last century.The casting of Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor was also an excellent choice. He portrays the character forcefully and his performance certainly elevates this film to a higher level.However, I must add that the performance of Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is much to be desired for. Her portrayal seems a bit rigid and I have always felt that something was missing in her character. But her acting was not too bad.In conclusion, if you are a fan of Superman, this is a must see movie. This movie, with its outstanding special effects certainly brings the whole superman franchise to a new level. Superman fans would not be disappointed with this latest portrayal of the "Man of steel".
summary: A good sequel to the original Christopher Reeves movies

reviewText: I didn't go into this film with any expectations, and ultimately I thought it carried the torch fairly well, in spirit.  There was enough overlap from the original film to fill in the storyline without clinging unnecessarily to its coattails.  Whether the story progression in this film would align with the comic universe itself...  I have my doubts.  If you are a stickler for the die hard comic characters, this film will not live up to your expectations.I did not find Brandon Routh to be a particularly stand out talent. I've never seen him in anything else.  He seemed to be moving along the plot without making any real contribution.  Spacey and Parker were quite the caricatures of their roles, all but stealing the film for their villainous depictions. Even with them, though, I felt like they were doing the best they could with a weak script.  Bosworth played a fairly subdued Lane, but in the end she came across more one-dimensional to me than just hyper focused on her work ethic while trying to hide a fiery passion for blue tights.  In fact,  she came off flat out cold in her interactions with her son, the enigma of which is deciphering who his real father is. With that interjection of doubt shadowing the little one you would think that with all this overwhelming love we are supposed to believe that she feels, that she would show a little more compassion to her son.  The majority of the characters were so bland that in the end I found myself not really caring if some of the principals didn't make it.  In fact, it would have been more in keeping with the canon storyline if...  well.  You just have to see it.The plot moved somewhat slowly in the middle, with quite a few leaps in logic (or flat out misinterpretations of the original Superman mythos) conveying it through its shallow and open climax.  There were no particularly dazzling special effects but the CGI maintained the comic vividness rather well.  Honestly I spent most of this film working out contradictions in my mind regarding collective consciousness, archetypes and which came first--the broken planet or the displaced hero, but I wouldn't expect those to convey well in a film review.  =)

I don't know what kind of motivation or agenda the writers, director, producers have, but I am SORELY disappointed in their cowardice in changing what an American icon Superman has been.Truth, Justice, and the American Way is not inane, it's idealistic optimism, which is exactly what Superman is.And then we get this line from Lois Lane: "The world doesn't need a Savior".You will find none of this type of dialogue in any of the  previous Superman presentations.Had they left their politics at home this would be a 4 or 5 star movie.

reviewText: When I saw that Bryan Singer was going to spearhead the Superman Returns project I was thrilled. Singer lead Marvel's X Men and X2...ummm...marvelously. So turning the helm over to Singer for DC Comic's Superman Returns was a big buzz.Perhaps Singer has been watching too much Smallville? Don't get me wrong, I think that Smallville is excellent. However, with Superman Returns my expectations were not set for a slow moving love story between Superman and Lois Lane...which is what 50% of the movie is; I would expect that kind of filler from Clark and Lana in the TV series Smallville...lot's of episodes to fill.Plus based on how action-oriented Singer's two X Men entries were, I had very high expectations for Superman Returns. The action was indeed good in Superman Returns, but it was predictable. There were no surprises. The special effects were good; the flying looked better than any Superman movie ever. But nothing that made me say out loud, "Oh, cooool" or "That is awesome!"And the story really fell flat. In fact, it was almost a re-do of Lex Luthor's quest for real estate in Superman 1. I've seen much better stories in the Justice League animated series than Superman Returns. Much better.Some of the situations in Superman Returns were very far fetched, i.e. (without revealing any spoiling details): Superman crashing via meteor back to earth with no public fanfare; Richard White rescuing Lois in a sea plane; Luthor Waltzing right into the Fortress of Solitude. I'd have liked to have seen more realistic scenarios like the excellent job David Goyer and Chris Nolan did with Batman Begins...just...more realistic.So perhaps Singer should have stuck with X Men 3 and let someone else have Superman Returns...but that is not the way the cookie crumbled. In fact, Singer has signed on for Superman: The Man of Steel scheduled for release in 2009.Brandon Routh was a pretty good Superman preserving the Christopher Reeve portrayal almost mirror image. Kevin Spacey was a good Lex. And Kate Bosworth was a bit young looking for Lois.After saying all this, I didn't think it was a bad movie. It just fell far short of what I expected. And that basically took a smile and turned it upside down.

reviewText: First of all, I think that this is in itself a good film. I applaud Brian Singer for the serious, respectful tone. (RE: X-Men 1 & 2) Really, this is the most serious Superman film to date. The thing, I think, and the reason that this was not a totally huge hit, and that WB is rebooting the franchise, is that this did not capture the hopeful, uplifting rush that we generally expect from Superman. The story and the visual look are both kind of muted and thoughtful, which is not a bad thing taken alone, but it is a little short on the "primary colors" that put stars in your eyes and a smile on your face.I would like to have seen more from Brandon Routh, certainly more dialogue. I don't have a problem with him. However, both he and Kate Bosworth seem young for the roles when you consider this film as a "sequel" to the first two Christopher Reeve films. Kevin Spacey is a good actor, yes, but I just don't see him as Lex Luthor. Also, the plot is very similar to Superman I.I think that Superman Returns coulda/shoulda taken a cue from Smallville, which for its occasional silliness *really* captures the essence of what makes Superman great, in addition to updating the cultural aesthetic to present day. Superman Returns seems to be paying homage, visually, to early incarnations (architecture, costumes, etc.) which, again, is classy but the nostalgia can be unnecessarily limiting. Summary: this is a good film, totally worth checking out, but not as great as it could have been. I have not yet gone through the special features, which look to be good.

reviewText: I am giving this movie one star for the special effects minus the obviously CGI flying scenes. I didn't really want to go see this mess in the first place because the lead was an unknown. But so many misguided movie goers told me that this was an excellent film. So you can imagine my dismay when I walked into the theater and paid my hard earned 11.75 to see this watered down dung heap of a film. First off, the acting was atrocious. The dialogue between the characters was abysmal and cheesy to say the least. The plot was corny and it dragged on like road kill from up under a bumper. In addition, whoever did the costume designing for superman's outfit must be blind!! His costume looked like something you could get from Walgreens around the Halloween season. Then they had the nerve to keep focusing the camera on these ugly black snow boots he was wearing. To sum up, this movie was a hot "nuclear explosion" of a mess and I would have rather spent two hours battling with constipation than be subjected to this horrific excuse for cinema.
summary: Horrendous!!!  Wretched!!!! Not even worth the price of a very cheap bootleg!!!

reviewText: I inserted my disc and was like, "where's the features?"  I didn't know that one had to buy the 2-disc special edition for the features.  I was rather disappointed because I wanted to see some sort of tribute to Christopher Reeves or something.  DVDs are too pricey to just have the movies on them.  Anyway, it's a really good movie.  Brandon Routh does a good job of playing Christopher Reeves playing Superman.  I wonder if he really studied the Superman movies of the 70s and 80s.  He really did the part justice.  As for Kate Bosworth as Lois, she did a fair job, but Margot Kidder made a better Lois.  Still, it's a really good movie; a fitting sequel to Superman 1 and 2 (let's all forget that 3 and 4 ever happened).

reviewText: Once John William's extraordinary score comes blasting out with the title Superman Returns popping up on the screen, and the credits flying across the screen (a nod to the original Superman film), I felt like jumping and cheering. Unfortunately, that was to be the most excitement I would get throughout the 150 minutes I spent watching the most disappointing sequel of the year so far.You can't help but watch Superman Returns and think about Christopher Reeve, Jackie Cooper, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman, Marc Maclure, and Marlon Brando (the only actor from the original that we actually see and hear in Returns). The reason why you can't stop thinking about those actors and hope you can see them onscreen instead of the actual actors who are in the film is because none of the actual stars, excluding Brandon Routh, convinces you that they are Perry White, Lois Lane, Lex Luthor, and Jimmy Olsen.Kate Bosworth is just too young (merely 23 years of age) and not vibrant enough to play Lois. Besides, there is no chemistry between her and Routh, who plays Clark Kent and Superman pretty swell! Kal Penn, who played Kumar in Harold And Kumar Go To White Castle, plays one of Luthor's thugs, but his character doesn't speak throughout the film (what a waste of comedic talent), the kid who plays Jimmy Olsen is not funny, and annoys you everytime he appears onscreen. Finally, there's Frank Langella (the man who played Skeletor opposite Dolph Lundgren's He-Man in Masters Of The Universe) who doesn't have the natural charm that Cooper brought to the Perry White character.Now let's talk about the script: horrendous. The plot and the plot twists are just one big mess aside from some unnecessary special effects and action sequences (the airplane crashing scene where Lois tumbles from one end of the airplane to another), and Clark Kent drinking beer (didn't Superman confess that he never drinks nor lies in his interview with Lois Lane in the original film? It seems Supe is a liar after all!). Warner seems to have rushed through pre-production picking one of the worse drafts of the scripts for production, but why? I'm not going to go into the details, but what were they thinking with the last 30 minutes of the film? Have they lost their minds? This is a Superman movie...not a Lois Lane movie (I hope those of you who saw it understand what I mean?).The only two good things about the movie are Brandon Routh and the opening credits and musical score. With that aside, Superman Returns flies flat on its face!Not recommended unless you're a gigantic Superman fanatic.D
summary: Superman Returns flies flat on its face!

reviewText: Bryan Singer has undertaken a potentially nightmarish gig for a director in taking on the film that is Superman Returns.  The production had a long and very well-documented road to seeing the light of day, having gone through the Tim Burton/Nicolas Cage proposal, signing and losing Brett Ratner and McG as directors, and commissioning scripts or treatments from the likes of Kevin Smith and JJ Abrams.  Singer, along with scribes Dan Harris and Michael Dougherty, goes the route of paying homage to the 1978 blockbuster that launched the career of Christopher Reeve.  "Returns" takes place five years after the events of Superman II (1980), but is set in the present.  Why? My theory is because Superman, like most of his superhero compatriots, works best when we can relate to him.  Superman (Brandon Routh, bearibng a striking resemblance to Reeve) has been gone for over five years, investigating the possibility that his homeworld of Krypton did not explode, only to return to a world that has mostly forgotten him.  Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth)is partially to blame for that, having won a Pulitzer for her editorial "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman."  She's engaged to a sort of human version of Superman, Richard White (James Marsden, who gives a nice, subtle performance), and has a 5 year old son, Jason(Tristan Lake Leabu).  Gruff Daily Planet Editor-In Chief Perry White (Frank Langella, a nice bit of casting) is glad to see one of his top reporters return, as is Clark's (and Superman's) pal, Jimmy Olsen(Sam Huntington, who is very fun to watch).  Not everyone is happy about the return of Supes, particularly Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey, unbelievably joyful to watch), who is hatching yet another scheme.  Lex's brilliance is hampered slightly by a new bumbling gang of idiots, headed by Parker Posey as Kitty Kowalski.The real treat is that Superman Returns maintains a lighthearted quality while embracing a slightly darker world.  Superman/Clark and Lois have more to contend with emotionally, and the world does seem a bit more cynical.  In the face of all this, there's a certain whimsy to it all, helped by the recycling of John Williams' themes in a new score by John Ottman.  This Superman is more drama, and a bit less action, but the action is quite a sight.  Singer clearly has great affection for Richard Donner's vision of the Man of Steel, but while he does capture some of the qualities of the character's 1978 incarnation, there's more exploration here of the internal troubles that our hero might be dealing with, namely isolation and the need to belong.  Only at teh end of the film do we feel like these issues are resolved for Superman, in a touching twist that may leave purists in an uproar.  With the exception of Kate Bosworth, all of the actors are brilliantly cast and shine in their roles.  Brandon Routh carries some of Christopher Reeve's mannerisms into Clark and Superman, but imbues the character with a deeper sense of personal anguish when it comes to his apparently failed relationship with Lois and his undying love for her.  He is clearly a star in the making.  Kevin Spacey was an obvious choice as Lex, and he brings both humor and menace to the classic villian, conveying a wonderfully nuanced and individual riff on Superman's most iconic nemesis.The reviews of this film have been widely divided: some love, some hate, some are indifferent.  As a kid who first saw the 1978 film, my first,  at a drive-in wearing Superman Pjs and a tie on cape at the age of 3 and a half and is a lifelong DC comics geek, I can't help but love this movie.  There are some bits that don't work, but they are brief.  The film does not achieve perfection, and it is not the definitive Superman film.  With the large mythology that has been built around the character, I doubt that such a thing could be made.  But it is to me a different version of what the Donner Superman is: a fantastical tale that breathes life into my first hero.  In my mind, it is a wirthy sequel to the first two films.  I would say it is a much better film than number two, which delved into more outright campiness and lost its hero (maybe the Richard Donner cut of film 2 will rectify that).  This is one of the better Superhero films to have been made, and is worth your money if you love the characters and are willing to allow them to mature. Final grade: A
summary: Refreshingly spirited homage - Superman still flies!

reviewText: I was generally disappointed in the movie Superman Returns.  It seemed like the ingredients were there, they just never jelled.  Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth both seemed way too young to have a backstory, and literally zero chemistry together.  There were serious lapses in the logic of the script as well.  Superman and Clark Kent both disappeared five years ago, and they both show up again on the same day with no one noticing?  And not only that, but after this long absence, Clark seems to just waltz into his old job at they Daily Planet as if nothing had happened?  I did like the rescue scene with the jet, however, in both these and other FX scenes, Superman's physique seemed to change to one much bigger.  In the scene in the hospital, where they took off Superman's shirt, his chest didn't look all that big.  This was as disconcerting as the animated flying sequences in the original Kirk Alyn serials.  Routh's costume had a strange rubbery look to it, and it was obvious they were aping the more beleagured Spiderman. I constantly felt like I wasn't watching a new Superman movie as much as a remake of a Christopher Reeve one.  Surely Superman has more villains than just Lex Luthor and his grand real estate schemes!  They even had the same John Williams score, and Marlon Brando's droning monotone.  I always thought that the first Reeve's movie toed the line of bad taste with that Marlon Brandon bit of monologue about giving us his only son in pseudo-Biblical language.  Superman Returns didn't just toe the line but stomped all over it.On the plus side I did like the Art Deco look, and the casting of both Perry White (Frank Langella) and Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington).  Although I would have prefered Brendon Frasier as Superman, he probably couldn't make as many sequels as Routh.  Like Batman Returns, I'm looking foreward to the sequel to see how they do without having to reintroduce the characters all over again.Whatever happened to super heroes with that certain joie de vivre?

reviewText: Superman Returns shows us just how much we have all missed Superman and still need him.  Of course, comparisons to Christopher Reeve are inevitable as he made the role his own, but Routh makes it his own as well.  Although he looks and sounds just like Reeve, intended by the studio no doubt, he is a good actor who brings depth to the role.  Okay, now for the specifics on the film:Plot: Well-conceived improvement over similar ideas presented in Superman I and II (slicing off California to enhance property value at the fault line and monkeying around with the Fortress of Solitude).  I also think it was a terrific idea to have this film pick up after Superman II where Lois and Superman, while reduce to a normal guy, get together.  This allows us to forget the dreaded sequels that followed and breathes life into the franchise with perhaps a "superboy" down the road.  In addition, this element in the story reminds us how Superman takes the high moral ground.  In Superman II he selfishly gave up his powers to sleep with Lois Lane and after realizing this error he sacrifices a normal life for the lonely hero life as the world still needs him.  To invade Lois's and his son's life at this point would be morally wrong and as equally selfish as when he gave up his powers in Superman II for a chance at a regular life and he knows it and, therefore, decides to step back from Lois and his own son's life (although we see he obviously cares when he observes them without them knowing it).  That's one big sacrifice and NOT a shirking of his duties as one reviewer here suggested.Character Development/Acting: Much time is devoted to character development than in most superhero films of the past (excluding X-Men and Spider-Man), especially regarding James Marsden of X-Men fame who is now Lois Lane's husband to be.  He has to struggle with the memory and return of the Man of Steel, and trying to be the best man for Lois and hero to his own son (who is really Superman's son).  He is very believable in this role.  Frank Langella is perfect as newspaper head and Lois Lane is wonderfully played by Kate Bosworth even to the point where you wish she was the original Lois Lane.  I never cared for Margot Kidder much in that role so I'm a bit bias here.  Of course, a superhero film isn't complete without the villain and Lex Luther as played by Kevin Spacey is perfect casting.  We never really feared Gene Hackman's Lex as he was a bit too cartoonish even though he damn near stole the second movie right out from under Superman.  Kevin is funny where he needs to be and punishingly ruthless where he has to be.Last, but not least is Brandon Routh, AKA Superman.  He knows he has big shoes to fill not just in Reeve's command of the role before him, but also in that many learned to love Reeve during his tragic post-Superman life wherein he really proved he was Superman with the courage he faced everyday while being a paraplegic.  I am one of those who grew to love and appreciate Christopher Reeve and I cried at his passing as did my children.  Someone new taking over this role established so well by a beloved actor has it's challenges and just as many are leary of Daniel Craig as the new Bond, some may be just as suspicious of Routh's Superman.  No need to be.  He pulls off the role with great skill and respect.  You can see the sadness in his eyes when he learns that Lois has moved on without him, had a son, is about to get married, and no longer believes the world needs Superman.  He is perfect for the role in spite of the studio's wish to simply find someone to mimic the looks of Reeve.  Routh is an acting find for this role and I look forward to seeing him in other roles as well.Director:  Who best to work behind the camera on this than veteran action TV series and X-Men movie director Bryan Singer.  He continues to prove his metal, forgive the pun, while working on the Man of Steel.  The story is well-paced between action sequences that are truly breathtaking and the plot and character development sequences.  He did a bang up job with this film.Special Effects:  Well, what is a superhero movie without them?  Those in this film are mind-boggling, especially the plane sequence in the early part of the film.  In fact, that sequence is probably the best in the film, but that doesn't mean the rest are poor, just not as good."Superman Returns" is fun for the whole family except those really young ones who might get a bit upset over the punishing beating Superman gets when he temporarily loses his powers late in the film.  That beating is rather graphic, hence the PG-13 rating.
summary: Superman Returns . . . And Boy was He Missed!

reviewText: I enjoyed this.  The special effects were excellent  - there's now virtually nothing they can't do, and everyone on the cast were talented and likable.But I have to subtract two stars because..this felt like the imitation of a great movie, rather than a great original work of Film.  I've seen so many Supermans that this one felt like a retread when it needed something vibrant and alive and new.They borrowed the Marlon Brando bit..virtually every word of dialog here sounded canned and predictable.  This is a kids movie..while the first two Superman films written by Mario Puzo (the Godfather series) really built a whole new legend and franchise. Brandon Routh's superman seems shallower .. He's likable, but he just doesn't have enough to say..probably because this is supposed to be a sequel to Superman II from 1981, so the whole stage has been set already.. But it's been 23 years and this is a new work, and as such it lacked personality.It's had a good opening weekend and generally good press, but I predict it won't have much staying power.  They spent $200M+ on this thing. There are better screenwriters out there..  Maybe next time.
summary: Fun to watch, within it's genre and scope

reviewText: First of all I would like to congatulate everyone behind this fantastic comeback. Superman fans couldn't have got it better.The fact that the replacement for the new Superman, Brandon Routh, being modelled after the late Christopher Reeve and his legacy is something to be lauded. The drop-dead handsome Brandon Routh excels on all fronts,  performance, style and looks. Kate Bosworth plays an adorable Louis and you couldn't ask for a better villian to replace Gene Hackman than the talented Kevin Spacey.With almost two decades of growth in special effects from the last Superman that we saw in the 80's, it was only anybody's guess that the special effects of Superman Returns had to be better. Superman Returns certainly doesn't disappoint those who came to watch this film for the effects alone. Amazing stuff.The plot and story aren't bad either. The nice twist in the end about Louis's son was the icing on the cake. The movie is engaging and never with a dull moment except for some of the concluding scenes.The only blooper of course is one that runs from the very first Superman movie. How come Louis or anyone else cannot identify the thinly disguised Clark Kent as Superman.Overall a great movie for the family and one that the late Christopher Reeve would have certainly been proud of.

reviewText: This was a good movie but it wasn't great.  To me there was so much potential with this movie but it didn't quite make it to the screen.  To its credit though it was an enjoyable movie I just think that it could have been a really great movie.Brandon Roth does an excellent job as Superman.  His angst over Lois, his battles agains Lex are all very genuine performances.  I think he fit the part of superman perfectly.The person whose role I was let down the most with is Lex Luther.  Kevin Spacey is a fantastic actor but his Lex was more deranged then mad  genius.  HIs plot to use Krptyon Crystals to grow land in the ocean was just absurd, there was no end of the world feeling to it. I felt more could have been done with Lex or some better plot could have been thought up.Kate Bosworth as Lois was just ok.  I think any pretty young starlet could have played Lois and no one would have noticed the difference.Although it may seem like I have more negative to say than positive about the movie, it was a good movie.  I was just expecting a lot more and didn't get it.  It is sad that the movie didn't do well b/c I feel with more Superman movies there was real potential to have a really good sequel.The Dvd: I watched the bare bones DVD version.  I take it there are so many versions so you will have to buy the deluxe special edition to even get a few special features.  This version had NONE.
summary: Great but Not as Good as it Could Have Been

reviewText: I really liked this movie. I am a big fan of super-hero movies (X-Men, Superman, and Batman mostly). I also like the CW's hit show Smallville which focuses on the early years of Clark Kent before he became Superman.This movie was really awesome. The special effects were amazing and breath-taking. Newcomer Brandon Routh made the legendary role of Clark Kent/Superman, (living two lives of a reporter and a superhero) his. No other actor could have done a better job. The story plot follows when Superman takes a bad fall and decides to take an absence of fighting crime. He doesnt even say good-bye. Meanwhile Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) manages to come up with a plan to destroy the world ( as usual). Superman must stop him or the whole world will be destroyed.Kate Bosworth ( Win a Date with Tad Hamilton!) did an excellent job as reporter Lois Lane, both Clark Kent and Superman's love interest. Lois mainly is infatuated with Superman and they share so much of chemical romance together. When he leaves, she is upset which causes her to write an article for The Daily Planet titled "Why the World Doesn't need Superman" which causes her to win The Pulitzer prize for best journalism. When Superman does return she falls in love with him all over again-but since he had taken an absense for many years Lois has had a son and a fiance named Richard (James Marsden). There is a bit of a love triangle in the movie.Each role has their own depth to it and the movie gets into their roles a lot. Obviously Superman does defeat Lex Luthor and his side-kicks. As well as his girlfriend Kitty ( Parker Posey).I really enjoyed watching this movie. Director Bryan Singer did a good job with the choice of actors for each role. There is some mystery about the child Lois has-could be Clarks. And also the sad thing is Superman doesnt end up with Lois. It may be possible to make a sequel but it wont be out for awhile is what I've heard. It also is kind of hard with the plot to make a sequel-if they want it to be better than the first. The sequel probably wont be out for 2 and a half-3 years. Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth, and Kevin Spacey should be back for the sequel. This movie gave breakthrough roles for Both Routh and Bosworth they probably have been offered many roles.We hope to see Superman soon!

reviewText: Superman is the man.  This movie is seeing the character on the big screen afetr a long time, but doesn;t reflect the complete character and his world.  Bryan Singer and his team seemed to have seen the first movie of Superman and that is it.  Watch the making of documentary and you will see one of his crew members reading "The Making Of Superman: The Movie" instead of a Superman comic book. This made me feel bad especially with my favorite superhero.  Why is it that the animated features and shows go full out with the enemies and stories until we hit film and there is this tied down feeling with only one villian, Lex Luthor...as if Braniac, Metallo, Darkseid, Toyman, Parasite, Titano, Lobo, Gog, Bloodsport, Atlas, Doomsday, and others would never be seen in Superman film universe (makes us feel lucky they used Zod for 1.2 films).  Also, switching the romance and add the child of _______ into the story makes no sense and illustrates no one did their homework.  Imagine if Peter Jackson made Lord of The Rings with only seeing the animated TV special Return Of The King in the 80s without reading any of the books, the trilogy would be a one movie deal and a musical.They did put a lot of hard work into the movie to make it look good, but I wish they tried more with the characters and the story.  That's difference with Batman Begins and Superman Returns...Christopher Nolan being more of a fan of the superhero's mythology rather than liking a few films of done in the past.The story is written from the outside looking into the character at a distance.  The movie is enjoyable to see Superman on the big screen but fails to give Superman the credit he has in the comic books.  It fails to take him to the next level of where he is now.  Smallville is doing a better job at the mythology.  Minus 2 stars for story and lack of work, but the movie is made well and may please anyone who doesn't know much about Superman but the basics to pass a Trivial Persuit game.  One golden rule is that Kryptonians cannot impregnate humans, this is not a hay wire sci fi world where different species genes can magically mix up.  This rule is broken.  Also Clark doesn't drink alcohol and Superman does appear in court...we even saw this in the Justice League animated series.I got this movie to support the Man Of Steel and the middle part is fun especially the airplane save & bullet eye shot.  Hang in there for the future for Superman and I highly recommend Superman: Doomsday and Superman/Batman: Public Enemies for those are way closer to the character and those great books.  Maybe in time DC and Warner Bros. will treat us with a wholesome Superman Motion Picture like Marvel made up for Hulk with Incredible Hulk.The makers of this film were clearly fans of the Superman movie and not Superman and it shows.
summary: A Superman " What If Story " or OK fan fiction

reviewText: What happens when you make a film in the year 2006 but make it as if it was the 1980's? Superman Returns is one giant homage to the original. From the opening theme you already know that Singer is in love with the original and wants nothing more then to recreate it for you in the guise of a "sequel".Four years have passed since Superman left on a wild goose chase and it seems time must have stopped still because this film tries so hard to emulate the first two films that it never becomes its own film. Its one giant wink and if you aren't winking back then this isn't going to be a fun ride.Everyone is miscast and the film has even less action then the original film. By the time they put Superman in the emergency room...if your not laughing as they try to work on him...well then you are taking this movie far too seriously.Thats the main problem is that Bryan Singer took this film way too seriously. Where's the American flag? Where's the modo "truth justice and the american way?" Its no where to be found and yet Spiderman has no problem displaying some good ol' american pride.Perhaps the sequel can liven things up but they have a long way to go and it may take a huge shake up at Warner Brothers to make it happen.

reviewText: It's nice to have Superman back but why did DC comics approve the storyline / plot that was made?  Superman represented "Truth, Justice, and the American Way", but with this movie it's "Truth, Justice and Child Support".  Superman a deadbeat dad??? Jeeeze, who at DC comics would allow such a whacked stoyline for it's flagship comic character???  My guess is DC was sooo desperate to ward off the Spiderman/X-Men/Fantastic Four popularity they settled for a sub-par story and it's to the detriment of the fans.  Brandon Routh did a credible job acting and Kevin Spacy was a good Luthor, but Kate whats-her-name was a terrible choice for Lois.  All in all, ig you are a hard-core Supes fan, you'll probably want this, others should stick to Chris Reeve's versions.
summary: Why did DC allow this storyline / plot ?

reviewText: Being a comic book fan for many many years, I was excited to hear about the new Superman movie finally coming out after many false starts, I know WB/DC is trying to re-jump start their characters back into the movies since Marvel has really taken it by storm now, I thought after such a long period that Superman would blast back to the screen better than ever.As Luthor said in the movie I was ..WRONGGGGGNot reading anything about the movie, just watching two trailers I went to see Superman returns, after the first 45 mins and the first action sequence, the Man of Steel started to rust for me, seeing the opening credits and hearing the familar theme music I thought great, paying homage to the first two movies, after watching the movie I sensed more of lifting entire parts of Superman 1 and altering them is not a homage, just lazy writing, such as Luthors land grab plot, aside from alterations it's the same as in Superman 1, his dumb girlfriend is named Kitty, but is just a Ms.Teschmacher clone, even using the same lines, and doing the same things, and the list goes on, but I don't want to do spoilers, believe me if you seen the first film you will recognize pretty fast the parts that were taken from it, I heard this was supposed to be a sequel to Superman 2, but it seemed more like a bad remake of Superman 1.Another thing I noticed was the horrible lack of action in this movie, once I got home and read the net I learned that Singer called this his first "chick flick movie" and that it was about old boyfriends coming back, what? 204 million and you make a love story, is this Superman ala Titanic? Since comics is a industry where the core demographic is men, why on Earth would Singer think fans would want to see Superman:The Love Story? Honestly there is a part of the movie that involves a hospital and Lois and I thought the theme to "Love Story" would start playing. I think hearing the fans talking about the lack of action Singer said a sequel would be his "wrath of khan" movie, with mucho action, if your a Star Trek fan, you would think that analogy is that Superman Returns is like Star Trek:The Motion Picture, very long, boring and just a showcase for improved special effects, where Wrath of Khan brought Star Trek back to where it should be, I would think you would want your first movie to be that kind of good, not boring and way to long.The roles were badly miscast, Bosworths portrayal of Lois Lane was about as wooden as you can get, not to mention way to young looking for a veteran journalist, and Superman is missing for 5 years and nobody, even his love Lois is worried, maybe he was kidnapped, killed..she writes "why the world doesn't need Superman" and wins a pulitzer, I would think it would be "Where is Superman?" and the chemistry between Routh and Bosworth well there was none, and Routh hardly said anything so who knows about his acting ablities.Singer not understanding the Superman character, after coming back from a 5 year abstence, finding out Lois is engaged and has a child, takes her on romantic flights, and seems to try and win her back,not very Superman like, oh and Superman drinks now,and uses his xray vision to spy on Lois, I don't think he smokes but who knows from Singers "loose sequel" "vague history" whatever it is, he might lie pretty good to as well.Singer and the writers can't figure out how Kryptonite works, or just didn't bother to research it, along with Superman himself that goes away from the love story,who cares about actually staying true to the character,it's the directors VISION that counts.Plotholes to many to even list..way to many.All in all, some nice effects, but very weak story, doesn't know if it's a remake or a sequel, the romance shouldn't be the main part of superhero movie, Luthor is good and all but in every Superman film as the villian? c'mon he has other villians, Brainiac or Parasite anyone,like having the Green Goblin as the villian in every Spidey movie. Wait for this as a rental.
summary: Superman Returns Just not as a good movie.

reviewerName: The Curmudgeon "Your life lacks purpose - my ...
reviewText: You gotta wonder what went through director Bryan Singer's head. After pretty much re-inventing the comic book movie wheel with the first two X-Men movies, he wisely stepped away from the franchise (resulting in the bloated dross that was X-Men: Last Stand), deciding to concentrate on a new superhero film, starring the world's best known hero.And guess what? It's even WORSE than the film he walked away from.For starters, Singer (along with seemingly the rest of the world) seems to think that the 1970s Superman movie, and in particular Christopher Reeve, are the only representations of the DC comic book. What's the first thing you read about new Supes Brandon Routh, what's the first thing people had to say about him? "Oh, he looks JUST like Christopher Reeve!" SO WHAT? Why is it so essential to stay fixated on those movies? Why do we never hear references made to the Kirk Alyn Superman? Or George Reeves, who (arguably) made an even bigger impact in the tights than his similarly named counterpart?But I digress. So, Superman Returns, then. Taken five years after Superman II (with Superman 3 and 4 being nixed from continuity - hmmm, messing around with continuity and carelessly discarding what's come before it? Yup, it's based on a DC comic, alright), we find that, for no real reason, Superman flew away for five years and let Lois Lane grow both more attractive and several years younger. That was nice of him. And wouldn't you know it, he's not back five minutes and already Lois is in dire peril - how did she survive all this time without him?While we're on the subject of Superman III and IV being wiped out because they were, well, crap, let's get one thing straight; the entire Superman FRANCHISE, including those holier than thou first two movies, aren't exactly perfect either. There are dozens of howlers in those movies, from Superman flying around the world so fast he turns back time (um, why not just do that for EVERYTHING bad that happens?), to Superman kissing Lois and WIPING HER MEMORY (it's Rohypnol Man!). Are we to pretend those things didn't happen as well?Anyway, in this one, what follows is a plot so ludicrous and half-baked you often wonder whether you should laugh or feel insulted. True, Superman is the most boring, two-dimensional character in comics, but even he deserves a better story than this. Spacey, a great actor, thinks hamming it up and yelling is all you need to be a great villain (if we're going to be obsessed with the 70s films, Gene Hackman was a much, much better Luthor), the chemistry between Lois and Clark is non-existent, and let's get to the REAL one-fingered salute to the fans, the franchise and the comic books themselves. If you want to avoid spoilers, look away now..Lois has a son from "another guy." Who, after playing piano with the nicest kidnapper in the world, suddenly reveals he has SUPER POWERS TOO. That's right - it's actually Superman's son! Not only would this be a biological impossibility, (wouldn't Clark's Super Sperm, just, you know, blast right through Lois?) but it also kills the entire series STONE DEAD. So, what, are we going to have SuperBoy in the next film (and make no mistake about it, Superman Returns is an obvious attempt at a franchise starter)? So we're basically going to ignore decades of continuity and just make stuff up for no reason?And then there's the fact that Superman isn't exactly, well, Super in this film to begin with. Yeah, he does some (nice looking) stuff like catching airplanes and having bullets bounce off his eyeballs, but when it really comes down to it, all he does it sulk, pick things up, and then get the snot beaten out of him by Luthor. Um.. awesome.It's a mess. A boring, pretentious, worthy mess. Which, in the days of spot-on comic book adaptations like Spider-Man 2 (and most recently Iron Man) is simply unacceptable.Send it to the Phantom Zone.
summary: Is it a bird?  Is it a plane?  No, its.. a colossal disappointment.

reviewText: "You wrote that the world doesn't need a savior, but, everyday I hear people crying for one."- The Man Of Steel tells (on again, off again girlfriend) Lois Lane one of the many reasons why "Superman Returns"Twenty-five summers after the release of "Superman II" & another roughly ten to fifteen years trying to get the project off the ground, Superman finally makes the leap back to the big screen in the aptly titled "Superman Returns". The results are mixed (I actually give the film ***1/2 stars).After the events of "Superman II", "Superman Returns" starts off with the Man Of Steel returning to Earth after a five year absence. It looked like astronmers had found the remains of what looked to be the burnt out planet of Krypton, Supes' his homeworld & Kal-El had to find out if anyone was home. Finding out that he truly is the last of his people, Superman returns to his real home, Earth.As for Superman's arch-nemesis Lex Luthor, he's free after Superman fails to show up for his parole hearing."How much do you think that pisses off Superman?", asks Jimmy Olsen."A lot.", replies an unamused Clark Kent, stunned by the news.Lex is also back in the green after swindling an inheritance from a millionairess, early on in the film.In the wake of Superman's mysterious dissapearance, the people of Metropolis realize that maybe they don't need a Superman afterall. That's the big question that Big Blue has to face. Will people accept his return? Do they really need him?Things don't actually look up for Clark Kent on his return to "The Daily Planet". Sure, he got his old job back, but, it's a one two punch that sends him to the local bar, in search of a drink, after finding out that Lois Lane has written a Pulitzer Prize winning essay on why the world doesn't need Superman, has moved on with her life with her five year old son & is engaged to Richard White, Perry's nephew, associate editor to "The Daily Planet", & father (?) to Lois' son.It's at the local sports bar, having a beer with Jimmy Olsen (the only one that seems happy to see him back), & a dangerous mishap with a NASA space shuttle, that Clark Kent makes up his mind to bring Superman back into the public eye.While most of the people of Earth embrace the return of Superman, two people aren't happy to see his arrival.Lois Lane, originally, heartbroken & now, angry has quite a few questions for her former boyfriend.As for Lex Luthor, he's making a huge land grab that will sink most of America underwater, thanks to some Kryptonian crystals pilfered from Superman's Fortress Of Solitude & Kryptonite stolen from a local museum.Of course, it's not a Superman film without Lois getting into trouble & all hell breaking loose thereafter. After some snooping around, trying to find out the cause of a mysterious citywide blackout, Lois, with her son in tow, accidently lands on a yacht that belongs to a freshly showered millonaire."Lex Luthor.""Lois Lane?!""Your bald."It's up to Superman to save Lois, her son (who may or might not have the White family blood running through him), & the U.S. of A from Lex Luthor's "Century 21" making disaster."Superman Returns" is one of those films that should be epic & fun, but, comes off big & by the numbers. I expected a lot more from director, Bryan Singer. There are quite a few loopholes to the film. "Returns" can't hold a match to the first two "Superman" films (those are still tops)."Superman Returns"' main & ultimately crippling problem is that it lacks the charm, warmth, & humor of "Superman: The Movie" & "Superman II" & this problem spreads throughout the film's lead charcter's. The chemistry between Lois & Superman is practically non-existent (they don't even kiss for God's sake!), & the big battle between Lex & Supes is lame & could be akin to a New York gang mugging.Brandon Routh does a passable job in the title role, but, in some scenes it seems as if Routh is doing an empty impression of Reeve. The classic Superman flyby that ends each "Super" film is mechanically done here. Oddly, of all the character's in the film Superman gets the least lines. The scenes where Superman secretly looks in on Lois & her family, & the scene where he watches, what might be his own son, sleeping are actually, & I hate to say it, a bit creepy.Kate Bosworth is too young to be playing Lois Lane. Her Lane is more of a smoking, soccer mom than a hard-nosed reporter. The thin plotline of Lois' son possibly being Superman's is just ludicrous. Remember, Superman gave up his powers in "II" in order to be with Lois. Only after learning about the Phantom Zone criminals taking over the world, did Supes go back & retrieve his super powers.Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor is one of the saving graces of "Superman Returns" (the action scenes are the other saving grace). His Luthor is more inline with Gene Hackman's portrayal than Spacey admits. However, Spacey doesn't bring that sense of menace that both Hackman & Michael Rosenbaum (Luthor in "Smallville") to their roles.  The scene where Luthor discovers Lois & her son aboard his yacht & the scene on the island near film's end are priceless. Parker Posey is dissmissable as Kitty (Posey was better as Gail Weathers in "Scream 3"). Valerie Perrine's, Miss Teschmacher & Ned Beatty's, bumbling Otis are sorely missed.The action scenes are pretty much what makes "Superman Returns" worth watching, especially the shuttle/airplane sequence.Superman's return is a welcome one but it's not an epic one."Superman Returns" flies home on DVD on November 28, 2006. Two editions will be available both in the 2.40:1 film aspect ratio. The first is either wide or full screen & contains just the film. The 2 disc edition has "Requiem For Krypton" - a 3 hr. doc on the making of "Superman Returns" & other features.
summary: The Man Of Steel "Returns" - The Results Are A Mixed Bag Of Kryptonite

reviewText: Who is the Man of Steel? This is an interesting take on the Superman series. Due to the classic nature of the first couple Superman films there was high expectations set for Superman Returns. An important note about this installment is that it is actually the fifth and final installment in the original Superman film series and serves as a sequel to Superman and Superman II. This film ignores the events of Superman III and Superman IV: The Quest for Peace. The basic premise is that Superman (Brandon Routh)  was gone for 5 years of soul searching and now he is back. At the same time the evil mastermind Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) is also back and plotting to take over the entire world. All the rest of the key characters are here as well and the film actually makes a successful transition from the original second installment of the series. Overall it is a great action packed return to form for the Man of Steel. A new character is also introduced in Superman Returns. As you watch the film you will find out who it this individual is and you may find the connection quite interesting.
